4f8e5b81e80eb0e413091588 2 7----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	doppler:1 phd:1 stefan:2 ies:1 univers:2 social:1 year:1 focus:1 head:1 work:2 czech:1 qualiti:2 flex:1 cdl:1 degre:3 project:1 system:1 fraunhof:1 professor:1 comput:1 empir:2 christian:1 depart:1 engin:3 schr:1 vienna:3 associ:1 econom:1 venia:1 spent:1 institut:1 scienc:2 softwar:4 technic:1 scholarship:1 manag:3 ms:2 receiv:3 erwin:1 research:4 technolog:1 docendi:1 dinger:1 tu:2 biffl:2 habilit:1 laboratori:1 guest:1 interact:1 cybernet:1	||	Stefan Biffl is an associate professor of software engineering at the Institute of Software Technology and Interactive Systems, TU Vienna. He received MS and PhD degrees in computer science from TU Vienna and an MS degree in social and economic sciences from the University of Vienna in 2001. He received an Erwin-Schr dinger research scholarship and spent one year as researcher at the Fraunhofer IESE, focusing on quality management and empirical software engineering. Also, in 2001 he received the Habilitation degree Venia Docendi for his work on empirical software engineering in project management and quality management. In 2006 he worked as guest researcher at Czech Technical University, Department of Cybernetics. Since 2010 Stefan Biffl is the head of the Christian Doppler research laboratory CDL-Flex .	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Institute of Software Technology and Interactive Systems; TU Vienna; TU Vienna; University of Vienna; Czech Technical University; Department of Cybernetics; Christian Doppler; 	PERSON: Stefan Biffl; Venia Docendi; Stefan Biffl; 	DATE: 2001; 2001; 2006; 2010; 	NOUN: Stefan Biffl; professor; software engineering; Institute; Software Technology; Interactive Systems; TU Vienna; MS; PhD degrees; computer science; TU Vienna; MS degree; sciences; University; Vienna; dinger research scholarship; year; researcher; Fraunhofer IESE; quality management; software engineering; Habilitation degree Venia Docendi; work; software engineering; project management; quality management; guest researcher; Czech Technical University; Department; Cybernetics; Stefan Biffl; head; Christian Doppler research laboratory; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Also, in 2001 I received the Habilitation degree (Venia Docendi) in "Praktische Informatik" for work on empirical software engineering in project management and quality management. 50d3bc892bafb0e4602992ee 3 2----Others----#text.SPAN.LI.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	da:2 yu:1 mahashweta:1 gautam:1 cong:1 yahia:1 sihem:1 saravanan:1 thirumuruganathan:1 amer:1	||	Mahashweta Das, Saravanan Thirumuruganathan, Sihem Amer-Yahia, Gautam Das, Cong Yu	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Cong Yu; 	PERSON: Mahashweta Das; Saravanan Thirumuruganathan; Sihem Amer-Yahia; Gautam Das; 	NOUN: Mahashweta Das; Saravanan Thirumuruganathan; Sihem Amer-Yahia; Gautam Das; Cong Yu; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
50d3bc892bafb0e4602992ee 3 3----Research----#text.DIV.LI.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	assign:1 gener:1 np:1 tag:10 etc:1 delici:1 perform:1 show:1 desir:1 center:1 help:1 search:1 rang:2 social:2 essenti:1 exact:1 adopt:1 phrase:1 action:1 import:1 effici:1 enabl:1 qualiti:1 involv:1 wide:2 without:1 solv:1 flickr:2 inform:1 appli:1 scenario:1 divers:5 compromis:1 word:1 demonstr:1 propos:1 result:1 defin:1 can:1 common:1 paper:1 behavior:1 data:1 typic:1 explor:1 signal:1 therefor:1 algorithm:2 character:1 dual:1 brute:1 real:1 rise:1 ie:1 concret:2 mine:2 comprehens:1 analysi:4 forc:1 complet:1 youtub:1 similar:5 site:1 implic:1 task:1 problem:2 web:1 analyz:1 photo:1 framework:3 around:1 differ:1 eg:1 oppos:1 compon:2 experi:1 item:4 approach:1 measur:2 significantli:1 certain:2 user:5 success:1 design:1	||	The rise of Web 2.0 is signaled by sites such as Flickr, del.icio.us, and YouTube, and social tagging is essential to their success. A typical tagging action involves three components, user, item (e.g., photos in Flickr), and tags (i.e., words or phrases). Analyzing how tags are assigned by certain users to certain items has important implications in helping users search for desired information. In this paper, we explore common analysis tasks and propose a dual mining framework for social tagging behavior mining. This framework is centered around two opposing measures, similarity and diversity, being applied to one or more tagging components, and therefore enables a wide range of analysis scenarios such as characterizing similar users tagging diverse items with similar tags, or diverse users tagging similar items with diverse tags, etc. By adopting different concrete measures for similarity and diversity in the framework, we show that a wide range of concrete analysis problems can be defined and they are NP-Complete in general. We design efficient algorithms for solving many of those problems and demonstrate, through comprehensive experiments over real data, that our algorithms significantly out-perform the exact brute-force approach without compromising analysis result quality.	##true@@false$$		||	NOUN: rise; Web; sites; Flickr; del. icio; YouTube; tagging; success; action; components; user; item; photos; Flickr; tags; words; phrases; tags; users; items; implications; users; information; paper; analysis tasks; mining framework; tagging behavior mining; framework; measures; similarity; diversity; components; range; analysis scenarios; users; items; tags; users; items; tags; measures; similarity; diversity; framework; range; analysis problems; algorithms; problems; experiments; data; algorithms; approach; analysis; quality; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

50d3bc892bafb0e4602992ee 3 6----Others----#text.SPAN.LI.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	lujun:1 da:1 bohannon:1 yu:1 sarma:1 fang:1 philip:1 cong:1 anish:1	||	Lujun Fang, Anish Das Sarma, Cong Yu, Philip Bohannon	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Cong Yu; 	PERSON: Lujun Fang; Anish Das Sarma; Philip Bohannon; 	NOUN: Lujun Fang; Anish Das Sarma; Cong Yu; Philip Bohannon; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
50d3bc892bafb0e4602992ee 3 7----Research----#text.DIV.LI.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	gener:1 challeng:1 desir:1 rank:2 given:1 thu:1 search:5 relat:2 effici:3 multipl:1 answer:1 complementari:2 log:1 statist:1 solv:1 present:2 queri:2 system:1 view:1 googl:1 explain:2 propos:1 novel:1 rex:3 pair:4 engin:3 data:1 commerci:1 algorithm:1 modern:1 enumer:1 interesting:1 leverag:2 yahoo:1 primari:1 direct:1 repres:2 web:1 research:1 puzzl:1 seek:2 relationship:7 either:1 experi:1 base:5 construct:1 world:1 explan:5 design:1 integr:1 perform:2 scalabl:1 conduct:1 indescrib:1 gather:1 enabl:1 behind:1 discov:2 node:1 input:1 formal:1 entiti:11 often:2 correl:1 properti:1 demonstr:1 meanwhil:1 call:1 defin:1 scale:1 furthermor:1 can:2 edg:1 connect:3 paper:1 knowledg:4 identifi:2 automat:1 microsoft:1 real:2 graph:1 extens:1 ie:1 dbpedia:1 implement:1 corrobor:1 analys:1 includ:1 variou:1 problem:2 list:1 analyz:1 manual:1 specif:1 effect:1 take:1 featur:1 approach:1 measur:1 user:3 studi:2	||	Knowledge bases of entities and relations (either constructed manually or automatically) are behind many real world search engines, including those at Yahoo!, Microsoft, and Google. Those knowledge bases can be viewed as graphs with nodes representing entities and edges representing (primary) relationships, and various studies have been conducted on how to leverage them to answer entity seeking queries. Meanwhile, in a complementary direction, analyses over the query logs have enabled researchers to identify entity pairs that are statistically correlated. Such entity relationships are then presented to search users through the "related searches" feature in modern search engines. However, entity relationships thus discovered can often be "puzzling" to the users because why the entities are connected is often indescribable. In this paper, we propose a novel problem called "entity relationship explanation", which seeks to explain why a pair of entities are connected, and solve this challenging problem by integrating the above two complementary approaches, i.e., we leverage the knowledge base to "explain" the connections discovered between entity pairs. More specifically, we present REX, a system that takes a pair of entities in a given knowledge base as input and efficiently identifies a ranked list of relationship explanations. We formally define relationship explanations and analyze their desirable properties. Furthermore, we design and implement algorithms to efficiently enumerate and rank all relationship explanations based on multiple measures of "interestingness." We perform extensive experiments over real web-scale data gathered from DBpedia and a commercial search engine, demonstrating the efficiency and scalability of REX. We also perform user studies to corroborate the effectiveness of explanations generated by REX.	##true@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Yahoo; Microsoft; Google; REX; REX; REX; 	NOUN: Knowledge bases; entities; relations; world search engines; Yahoo; Microsoft; Google; knowledge bases; graphs; nodes; entities; edges; relationships; studies; leverage; entity; queries; direction; analyses; query logs; researchers; entity pairs; entity relationships; users; searches; feature; search engines; entity relationships; users; entities; paper; problem; entity relationship explanation; pair; entities; problem; approaches; leverage; knowledge base; connections; entity pairs; REX; system; pair; entities; knowledge base; input; list; relationship explanations; relationship explanations; properties; algorithms; relationship explanations; measures; interestingness; experiments; data; DBpedia; search engine; efficiency; scalability; REX; user studies; effectiveness; explanations; REX; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

50d3bc892bafb0e4602992ee 3 11----Research----#text.DIV.LI.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	demo:1 maprat:2 detail:1 understand:1 simpl:1 overal:1 etc:1 desir:1 help:1 becom:1 interest:1 among:1 movi:2 along:1 form:1 multipl:1 provid:1 yelp:1 inform:3 input:1 system:1 visual:1 plethora:1 popular:1 explain:1 judgment:1 defin:1 compet:1 can:1 allow:2 decis:1 paper:1 set:1 interpret:1 explor:3 systemat:1 imdb:1 chosen:1 aggreg:4 build:1 resourc:1 rate:6 collabor:2 associ:1 carefulli:1 choos:1 demograph:1 meaningfulli:1 consult:1 invit:1 site:2 analyt:1 rich:1 particip:1 averag:1 dimens:1 quickli:2 eg:1 either:1 pattern:1 decid:1 pre:1 item:5 user:8	||	Collaborative rating sites such as IMDB and Yelp have become rich resources that users consult to form judgments about and choose from among competing items. Most of these sites either provide a plethora of information for users to interpret all by themselves or a simple overall aggregate information. Such aggregates (e.g., average rating over all users who have rated an item, aggregates along pre-defined dimensions, etc.) can not help a user quickly decide the desirability of an item. In this paper, we build a system MapRat that allows a user to explore multiple carefully chosen aggregate analytic details over a set of user demographics that meaningfully explain the ratings associated with item(s) of interest. MapRat allows a user to systematically explore, visualize and understand user rating patterns of input item(s) so as to make an informed decision quickly. In the demo, participants are invited to explore collaborative movie ratings for popular movies.	##true@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: IMDB; 	NOUN: rating sites; IMDB; Yelp; resources; users; judgments; items; sites; plethora; information; users; aggregate information; aggregates; rating; users; item; aggregates; dimensions; user; desirability; item; paper; system MapRat; user; details; set; user demographics; ratings; item; s; interest; MapRat; user; user rating patterns; input item; s; decision; demo; participants; movie ratings; movies; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Those knowledge bases can be viewed as graphs with nodes representing entities and edges representing (primary) relationships, and various studies have been conducted on how to leverage them to answer entity seeking queries. Meanwhile, in a complementary direction, analyses over the query logs have enabled researchers to identify entity pairs that are statistically correlated. Such entity relationships are then presented to search users through the "related searches" feature in modern search engines. However, entity relationships thus discovered can often be "puzzling" to the users because why the entities are connected is often indescribable. In this paper, we propose a novel problem called "entity relationship explanation", which seeks to explain why a pair of entities are connected, and solve this challenging problem by integrating the above two complementary approaches, i.e., we leverage the knowledge base to "explain" the connections discovered between entity pairs. More specifically, we present REX, a system that takes a pair of entities in a given knowledge base as input and efficiently identifies a ranked list of relationship explanations. We formally define relationship explanations and analyze their desirable properties. Furthermore, we design and implement algorithms to efficiently enumerate and rank all relationship explanations based on multiple measures of "interestingness." We perform extensive experiments over real web-scale data gathered from DBpedia and a commercial search engine, demonstrating the efficiency and scalability of REX. We also perform user studies to corroborate the effectiveness of explanations generated by REX.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Yahoo; Microsoft; Google; REX; REX; REX; 	NOUN: Knowledge bases; entities; relations; world search engines; Yahoo; Microsoft; Google; knowledge bases; graphs; nodes; entities; edges; relationships; studies; leverage; entity; queries; direction; analyses; query logs; researchers; entity pairs; entity relationships; users; searches; feature; search engines; entity relationships; users; entities; paper; problem; entity relationship explanation; pair; entities; problem; approaches; leverage; knowledge base; connections; entity pairs; REX; system; pair; entities; knowledge base; input; list; relationship explanations; relationship explanations; properties; algorithms; relationship explanations; measures; interestingness; experiments; data; DBpedia; search engine; efficiency; scalability; REX; user studies; effectiveness; explanations; REX; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6be80eb0e45c021588 4 2----Employment----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	employe:1 distribut:1 carri:1 industri:1 faculti:1 middlewar:1 close:1 constitu:1 cover:1 student:2 univers:5 interest:1 rang:2 among:1 social:1 partner:1 focus:1 medicin:1 fourteen:1 head:1 topic:1 mobil:2 german:1 avail:1 involv:1 wide:2 dresden:2 largest:1 sap:1 project:2 system:3 daimlerchrysl:1 program:1 professor:1 commun:1 comput:3 known:1 oldest:1 siemen:1 alexand:1 depart:1 engin:1 state:1 teleservic:1 network:2 prof:1 collabor:2 schill:1 name:1 institut:1 scienc:3 dr:1 addit:1 includ:1 technic:1 offer:1 ubiquit:1 research:2 technolog:3 human:1 field:1 multimedia:1 focu:1 architectur:1 nearli:1 intern:1 group:1 studi:2 saxoni:1 found:1	||	The Dresden University of Technology, founded in 1828, is among Germany's oldest universities with technical focus. It is the largest university in the German state of Saxony, with about 34600 students and nearly 4000 employees, including 438 professors. Fourteen faculties cover a wide range of fields in science and engineering, humanities, social sciences and medicine. In addition to the wide range of studies available to students, the university offers 16 programs for international studies. The Computer Networks Group involved in the project is a constituent of the Institute for Systems Architecture at the Department of Computer Science at Dresden University of Technology. It is headed by Prof. Dr. Alexander Schill. The research interests are focused on networking technology topics, namely Distributed Systems and Middleware, Mobile Communication and Mobile/Ubiquitous Computing, Teleservices and Collaborative Systems, and Multimedia. Most of our research projects are carried out in close collaboration with well-known industrial partners like DaimlerChrysler, Siemens and SAP.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Dresden University of Technology; Computer Networks Group; Institute for Systems Architecture; Department of Computer Science; Dresden University of Technology; Distributed Systems and Middleware; Teleservices and Collaborative Systems; DaimlerChrysler; Siemens; SAP; 	PERSON: Dr. Alexander Schill; 	LOCATION: Germany; Saxony; 	NOUN: Dresden University; Technology; Germany; universities; focus; university; state; Saxony; students; employees; professors; faculties; range; fields; science; engineering; humanities; sciences; medicine; addition; range; studies; students; university; programs; studies; Computer Networks Group; project; constituent; Institute; Systems Architecture; Department; Computer Science; Dresden University; Technology; Prof. Dr. Alexander Schill; research interests; technology topics; Systems; Middleware; Mobile Communication; Mobile\/Ubiquitous Computing; Teleservices; Collaborative Systems; Multimedia; research projects; collaboration; partners; DaimlerChrysler; Siemens; SAP; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e45c021588 4 3----Research----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	reconfigur:1 person:1 integr:1 ontolog:1 reason:2 singl:1 servic:5 distribut:1 languag:1 uml:1 middlewar:1 sensor:1 contribut:1 deal:1 scheme:2 combin:1 place:1 dynam:1 mda:1 mof:1 platform:3 support:1 enabl:1 mobil:2 signific:1 environ:3 describ:1 avail:1 logic:1 system:1 entiti:1 comput:1 sourc:2 execut:1 vari:1 placement:1 model:2 concept:2 infrastructur:2 depart:1 partit:1 engin:2 adapt:6 osgi:1 net:1 network:1 applic:5 wireless:1 area:2 heterogen:2 implement:2 especi:1 develop:1 major:1 similar:1 peer:2 softwar:1 uncertain:1 includ:3 variou:1 us:1 web:2 ubiquit:1 research:1 technolog:1 achiev:1 orient:1 compon:4 term:1 experi:2 interfac:2 replac:1 base:7 context:6 awar:2 approach:2 devic:1 within:1 probabilist:1 user:2 design:2	||	The department of computer networks has long term experiences in the design and implementation of adaptive platforms, user interfaces and applications for heterogeneous and dynamic infrastructures in mobile and ubiquitous environments. Major experiences in the area of adaptive applications and user interfaces include: Language concepts based on the single source approach; an adaptation engine as service platform for adaptive web-based applications; component-based and service-oriented approaches for adaptive middleware platforms based on Web Services, .Net, OSGi and similar component technologies; concepts for the partitioning of applications in mobile environments and the placement of components (especially for adaptation) within a distributed infrastructure, including replaceable and reconfigurable component-based services; and software engineering support for the development of context-aware applications and systems based on MDA, MOF and UML Modelling schemes. In the area of context-awareness, significant research contributions have been achieved, including the design and implementation of a peer-to-peer context-service, which enables the modelling and reasoning about uncertain context; integration of probabilistic and logic based reasoning schemes to deal with varying availability and combinations of wireless sensors and other heterogeneous context sources; and the use of ontologies to describe the context of various entities (such as devices, persons, and places as well as executing environments).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: MDA; MOF; UML; 	NOUN: department; computer networks; term experiences; design; implementation; platforms; user interfaces; applications; infrastructures; environments; experiences; area; applications; user interfaces; Language concepts; source approach; adaptation engine; service platform; applications; approaches; platforms; Web Services; Net; OSGi; component technologies; concepts; partitioning; applications; environments; placement; components; adaptation; infrastructure; services; software engineering support; development; applications; systems; MDA; MOF; UML; schemes; area; context-awareness; research contributions; design; implementation; context-service; modelling; reasoning; context; integration; logic; reasoning schemes; availability; combinations; sensors; context sources; use; ontologies; context; entities; devices; persons; environments; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

The working world of the 21 st Century requires more skill, more productivity, more independent thought and greater innovation from its workforce than any other time in human history. With so many choices, why should you turn to Technological University of America (TUA)? When you choose TUA, you choose more than a school, you choose a partner that will elevate your thinking, challenging you to reach for greater heights as you blaze your path on the road of life. Technical knowledge, particularly in Science and Engineering, is doubling about every five years. Some estimates say in 10 years knowledge will double in less than six months. How will you keep up? At TUA we meet these challenges by maintaining an enduring commitment to educating tomorrow's Technology Leaders for Career Success and preparing students for tomorrow's global economy. Our Professional Education unit helps professionals stay up-to-date with the cutting-edge technology. We stand by the quality and excellence of our programs and we are committed to the successful enhancement of your professional career. To that end we provide excellent instruction, technology designed to deliver that instruction, and an infrastructure aimed at supporting your efforts. I invite you to make a closer inspection and review TUA's acclaimed undergraduate and graduate programs and courses then join our community of learners who wish to continue their education and stay on the forefront of technology to meet the challenges of the 21st century.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Technological University of America; TUA; Technology Leaders for Career Success; Professional Education; 	PERSON: TUA; TUA; 	NOUN: Today; fields; world; st Century; skill; productivity; thought; innovation; workforce; time; history; choices; Technological University; America; TUA; TUA; school; partner; thinking; heights; path; road; life; Technical knowledge; Science; Engineering; years; estimates; years knowledge; months; TUA; challenges; commitment; tomorrow; Technology Leaders; Career Success; students; tomorrow; economy; Education unit; professionals; technology; quality; excellence; programs; enhancement; career; end; instruction; technology; instruction; infrastructure; efforts; inspection; review TUA; programs; courses; community; learners; education; forefront; technology; challenges; century; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 6----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	artifici:1 geographi:1 furthermor:1 engin:1 intellig:1 geograph:1 perform:1 biologi:1 disciplinari:1 contribut:2 area:2 civil:1 geodesi:1 scienc:3 wherea:1 spatial:2 come:2 us:1 research:3 geologi:1 databas:1 inform:1 differ:1 appli:1 cartographi:1 plan:1 gi:3 multi:1 comput:2 geometri:1 archaeolog:1	||	Geographic Information Science (GIS) is a multi-disciplinary research area. Contributions from the spatial sciences come from geodesy, geography, and cartography, whereas contributions from computer science come from databases, artificial intelligence, and computational geometry. Furthermore, very different research areas where GIS are used, like spatial planning, archaeology, geology, civil engineering and biology, also perform applied research in GIS.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Geographic Information Science; 	LOCATION: GIS; 	NOUN: Information Science; GIS; research area; Contributions; sciences; geodesy; geography; cartography; contributions; computer science; databases; intelligence; geometry; research areas; GIS; planning; archaeology; geology; engineering; biology; research; GIS; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 7----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	graphic:1 memori:1 can:1 structur:1 proven:1 cours:1 data:1 foundat:1 algorithm:1 time:2 path:1 domain:1 geometr:2 develop:2 addit:1 vision:1 mathemat:1 worst:1 robot:1 problem:1 game:1 imag:1 solv:1 techniqu:1 process:1 differ:1 appli:1 plan:1 gi:1 often:1 base:1 comput:4 theori:1 case:1 geometri:2 bound:1 medic:1	||	Computational geometry is all about doing geometric computations by the computer. For this, (additional) theory is being developed based on the foundation of mathematics. Data structures and algorithms are developed to solve geometric problems often with proven worst-case (and some times also with other) time and memory bounds. Computational geometry techniques can be, and are applied in many different domains: vision, path planning, gaming, graphics, robotics, medical image processing, and of course also in GIS.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: geometry; computations; computer; theory; foundation; mathematics; Data structures; algorithms; problems; times; time; memory bounds; geometry techniques; domains; vision; path planning; gaming; graphics; robotics; image processing; course; GIS; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 8----Presentation----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	need:1 result:1 commiss:1 understand:1 last:1 contact:1 informati:1 interest:1 geometr:1 develop:1 netherland:2 coordin:1 wherea:1 futur:1 nederland:1 geo:2 devot:1 dai:1 research:1 jointli:1 relationship:1 field:1 peopl:1 inform:1 seminar:2 organ:1 geodet:1 gi:3 aim:1 comput:5 interact:1 method:1 improv:1 strengthen:1 studi:1 geometri:3 hope:1	||	The seminar 'Geo-Information and Computational Geometry' of the Netherlands Geodetic Commission (jointly organized with Geo Informatie Nederland) was devoted to the relationships between GIS and computational geometry. In a GIS, computations with coordinates are needed, whereas computational geometry is about developing methods to do so. The seminar aimed to improve the understanding of the two research fields, so that interaction in the future is further strengthened. We hope that the study day has resulted in lasting new contacts between all people in the Netherlands with an interest in geometric computing in GIS.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Netherlands Geodetic Commission; Geo Informatie Nederland; 	LOCATION: Netherlands; GIS; 	NOUN: seminar; Geo-Information; Computational Geometry; Netherlands Geodetic Commission; Geo Informatie Nederland; relationships; GIS; geometry; GIS; computations; geometry; methods; seminar; understanding; research fields; interaction; future; study day; contacts; people; Netherlands; interest; computing; GIS; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 9----Presentation----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	relev:1 tool:1 possibl:1 object:1 contribut:3 rang:1 vector:1 domain:1 topic:1 spatial:1 problem:1 solv:1 techniqu:1 field:1 seminar:1 differ:1 raster:1 specif:1 either:1 overview:1 gi:1 divers:1 base:2 comput:1 interact:1 public:1 geometri:1 reflect:2	||	The contributions reflect the diversity of the possible interactions between computational geometry and GIS. The topics of the contributions range from overviews of relevant techniques and tools to solving specific spatial problems in either the object-based (vector) or field-based (raster) domain. This publication is a reflection of the different seminar contributions.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: contributions; diversity; interactions; geometry; GIS; topics; contributions; overviews; techniques; tools; problems; vector; raster; domain; publication; reflection; seminar contributions; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 10----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	understand:1 simpl:1 approxim:1 univers:1 basic:1 relat:1 effici:5 marc:1 sensit:1 involv:1 avail:1 solv:1 gi:3 comput:5 case:1 output:1 geometri:5 defin:1 idea:1 concept:1 van:1 sort:1 paper:1 state:1 object:2 introduc:1 algorithm:7 indirect:1 provabl:1 simpler:1 indic:1 realist:1 current:1 geometr:1 analysi:2 find:1 direct:1 softwar:1 includ:1 worst:1 librari:1 problem:4 us:2 main:2 focu:1 intract:1 kreveld:1 improv:1 utrecht:1 complic:1 assumpt:1	||	The first paper 'Computational Geometry: Its objectives and relation to GIS' is by Marc van Kreveld (Utrecht University). The analysis of algorithms involves understanding how efficiently an algorithm solves a problem. One of the main objectives of computational geometry is finding the most efficient algorithms for all sorts of geometric problems. He introduces the main concepts and ideas in computational geometry, including efficiency analysis, intractability, output-sensitive algorithms, and approximation algorithms. The basic problems of computational geometry all have a direct or indirect use to GIS. He also indicates why computational geometry is not as useful to GIS as it could be (complicated algorithms, focus on worst-case efficiency, and on well-defined, simple to state problems) and how this is currently improving (available software libraries, simpler algorithms provably efficient under realistic assumptions).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Utrecht University; 	PERSON: Marc van Kreveld; 	NOUN: paper; Geometry; objectives; relation; GIS; Marc van Kreveld; Utrecht University; analysis; algorithms; algorithm; problem; objectives; geometry; algorithms; sorts; problems; concepts; ideas; geometry; efficiency analysis; intractability; algorithms; approximation algorithms; problems; geometry; use; GIS; geometry; GIS; algorithms; focus; efficiency; state problems; software libraries; algorithms; assumptions; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 11----Others----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	berg:1 memori:5 disk:2 time:2 level:2 effici:2 consist:1 eindhoven:1 descript:1 mark:1 obtain:1 often:1 discuss:1 comput:1 explain:1 geometri:1 result:1 structur:2 implicitli:1 set:1 paper:2 data:5 typic:1 issu:1 quit:1 recent:1 applic:1 algorithm:4 de:1 fit:1 slower:1 name:1 practic:1 hierarch:1 assum:1 includ:1 spatial:2 cach:3 access:2 sever:1 main:3 handl:1 techniqu:1 differ:2 tu:1 focu:1 address:1 larg:2 design:1	||	Mark de Berg (TU Eindhoven) addresses one of the issues to make computational geometry techniques more applicable in practice, namely the handling of large data sets that do not fit in main memory (as often more or less implicitly assumed in the description of many data structures and algorithms). In his paper 'I/O- and Cache-efficient Algorithms for Spatial Data' he explains how the hierarchical memory consisting of a disk, main memory, and several levels of cache should be included in data structure and algorithm design. The difference between the times to access these different levels of memory is quite large: the disk is typically about 100,000 times slower than accessing the main memory. In the paper some of the recent results that have been obtained on I/O- and cache-efficient algorithms are discussed with focus on spatial data.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: TU Eindhoven; 	PERSON: Mark de Berg; 	NOUN: Mark de Berg; TU Eindhoven; addresses; issues; geometry techniques; practice; handling; data sets; memory; description; data structures; algorithms; paper; Algorithms; Spatial Data; memory; disk; memory; levels; cache; data structure; algorithm design; difference; times; levels; memory; disk; times; memory; paper; results; I\/O; algorithms; focus; data; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##true@@true$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 12----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	integr:1 relev:1 permit:1 connected:1 perform:1 directli:1 oper:4 univers:1 rang:1 lidar:2 light:1 creat:1 descript:1 describ:1 extract:1 topolog:1 surfac:1 appli:1 updat:1 flood:1 properti:1 boundari:1 tunnel:1 creation:1 model:5 landscap:1 tse:1 edg:3 structur:2 paper:1 data:4 christoph:1 object:4 build:2 automat:1 applic:1 mai:1 extrus:2 rebecca:1 bridg:1 gold:1 triangl:1 man:2 terrain:1 detect:1 uk:1 elev:1 edit:1 variou:1 us:3 research:1 manual:1 specif:1 dimension:1 quad:3 term:1 euler:2 base:2 glamorgan:1 local:1 earth:1 insert:1 modif:1	||	One specific data structure, based on quad-edges, and applied to creating and editing three-dimensional models, is described by Christopher Gold and Rebecca Tse (University of Glamorgan, UK) in their paper 'Quad-Edges and Euler Operators for Automatic Building Extrusion Using LiDAR Data' (LIght Detection And Ranging). The long-term research objective for their models is to integrate man-made objects with the landscape, so that topological properties, such as connectedness, may be used in applications such as flood modeling. Man-made objects such as buildings, as well as terrain elevation, should be extracted directly from LiDAR data. Their model is a triangle-based boundary description of the relevant objects and earth surface. The model creation and local modifications (updates) is performed on the Quad-Edge data structure by using Euler operators. These operators permit various extrusion operations as well as the manual insertion of bridges and tunnels.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Christopher Gold; University of Glamorgan; 	PERSON: Rebecca Tse; Euler; 	LOCATION: UK; 	NOUN: data structure; quad-edges; editing; models; Christopher Gold; Rebecca Tse; University; Glamorgan; UK; paper; Quad-Edges; Euler Operators; Automatic Building Extrusion; LiDAR Data; LIght Detection; Ranging; research objective; models; objects; landscape; properties; connectedness; applications; flood modeling; objects; buildings; terrain elevation; LiDAR data; model; boundary description; objects; earth surface; model creation; modifications; updates; Quad-Edge data structure; Euler operators; operators; extrusion operations; insertion; bridges; tunnels; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 13----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	rectangular:3 cartogram:8 test:1 gener:2 proport:1 tool:2 variabl:1 particular:2 show:1 good:1 given:1 focus:1 adjac:1 cartograph:2 symbol:1 intuit:1 eindhoven:1 descript:1 preserv:1 shape:1 statist:1 solv:1 size:1 recogniz:1 visual:2 discuss:1 comput:3 small:1 geometri:1 countri:1 region:4 furthermor:1 counti:1 can:1 give:1 set:1 paper:2 correspond:1 data:1 state:1 geograph:1 therefor:1 rectangl:1 algorithm:2 short:1 bettina:1 pleas:1 practic:1 map:2 implement:1 error:1 repres:1 briefli:1 variou:1 us:3 problem:1 speckmann:1 specif:1 effect:1 tu:1 overview:1 special:1 keep:1	||	A description of the use computational geometry tools used to solve a few specific cartographic problems is given by Bettina Speckmann (TU Eindhoven) in her paper 'Algorithms for cartograms and other specialized maps'. Cartograms are a useful and intuitive tool to visualize statistical data about a set of regions like countries, states or counties. The size of a region in a cartogram corresponds to a particular geographic variable and therefore the regions generally cannot keep both their shape and their adjacencies. A good cartogram, however, preserves the recognizability in some way. The paper gives a short overview of cartogram algorithms, and focuses in particular on the computation of rectangular cartograms. In a rectangular cartogram each region is represented by a rectangle. An implementation and various tests show that in practice, visually pleasing rectangular cartograms with small cartographic error can be generated effectively. Furthermore, the computation of proportional symbol maps is also discussed briefly.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Bettina Speckmann; 	NOUN: description; use; geometry tools; problems; Bettina Speckmann; TU Eindhoven; paper; Algorithms; cartograms; maps; Cartograms; tool; data; set; regions; countries; states; counties; size; region; cartogram; variable; regions; shape; adjacencies; cartogram; recognizability; way; paper; overview; cartogram algorithms; computation; cartograms; cartogram; region; rectangle; implementation; tests; practice; cartograms; error; computation; symbol maps; briefly; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 14----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	ten:2 tetrahedron:2 constrain:1 gener:1 accept:1 perform:1 challeng:1 tin:1 penninga:1 amount:1 contrast:1 becom:1 realiz:1 enorm:1 border:1 delft:1 work:1 topic:1 final:1 enabl:1 remov:1 partial:1 surfac:1 updat:2 separ:1 whole:1 friso:1 irregular:2 known:1 face:1 defin:1 primit:1 result:2 model:3 complex:1 edg:1 tse:1 structur:2 correspond:1 set:1 paper:1 data:4 constraint:2 biggest:1 triangul:1 therefor:1 object:1 network:3 algorithm:2 version:1 reach:1 afterward:1 order:1 gold:1 addit:1 robust:1 tetrahedr:1 repres:3 topograph:3 equal:1 join:1 despit:1 potenti:1 sever:1 handl:1 process:2 dimension:2 tu:1 dataset:1 within:1 bound:1	||	Three-dimensional topographic modeling is also the topic of the paper by Friso Penninga (TU Delft): 'Constrained tetrahedral models and update algorithms for topographic data'. In contrast to the work of Gold and Tse he does not do this by representing the bounding surfaces, but he represents the three-dimensional objects by sets of tetrahedrons. The whole model then becomes a tetrahedronized irregular network (TEN), the 3D version of the more generally known triangulated irregular network (TIN). The TEN is a well-defined and robust data structure which enables complex processing by separate processing on each primitive first and afterwards joining all these partial results into a final result. In order to represent their borders several edges and faces will be handled as constraints. Updating a topographic dataset therefore equals the addition and removal of constraints within the network. One of the biggest challenges in the realization of such a data structure and corresponding algorithms is to reach acceptable performance, despite the potentially enormous amount of data.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Friso Penninga; 	LOCATION: Delft; 	NOUN: modeling; topic; paper; Friso Penninga; TU Delft; models; algorithms; data; contrast; work; Gold; Tse; surfaces; objects; sets; tetrahedrons; model; network; 3D version; network; TIN; data structure; complex processing; processing; results; result; order; borders; edges; faces; constraints; dataset; addition; removal; constraints; network; challenges; realization; data structure; algorithms; performance; amount; data; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 15----Research----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	last:1 derek:1 languag:5 challeng:1 function:1 contrast:1 time:3 requir:1 deal:1 toward:1 scheme:1 univers:1 forward:2 propag:1 dynam:1 counterpart:1 support:1 calcul:1 embed:1 input:1 simul:4 environment:3 gi:1 mont:2 often:2 program:1 output:1 solut:1 defin:1 call:1 model:6 structur:1 paper:2 carlo:2 state:2 data:3 object:2 pcraster:1 run:1 quit:1 applic:1 algorithm:1 de:1 inclus:1 real:1 kor:1 extens:1 grid:1 futur:1 error:1 spatial:3 regular:1 us:2 dimens:1 techniqu:1 represent:2 field:2 process:1 preced:1 differ:1 karssenberg:1 jong:1 base:4 approach:1 improv:1 construct:1 utrecht:1 world:1 step:1	||	The last paper 'Towards improved solution schemes for Monte Carlo simulation in environmental modeling languages' is by Derek Karssenberg and Kor de Jong (Utrecht University). They deal with the field-based representation of spatial data, in contrast to the object-based representation of spatial data in the other papers. On the most often used field-based data structure, the regular grid, the algorithmic challenges are quite different than their counterparts in the object-based approaches. Environmental modeling languages such as PCRaster are programming languages embedded in GIS to simulate environmental processes. These languages are used to construct dynamic models, also called forward models, which are simulations run forward in time, where the state of the model at time t is defined as a function of its state in a time step preceding t. For future applications, at least two extensions to the languages are required: support of three spatial dimensions (as the real world is often 3D), and inclusion of Monte Carlo simulation techniques (to calculate how input errors propagate to the output of a model).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Monte Carlo; Utrecht University; 	PERSON: Derek Karssenberg; Kor de Jong; 	LOCATION: Monte Carlo; 	NOUN: paper; solution schemes; Monte Carlo simulation; modeling languages; Derek Karssenberg; Kor; Jong; Utrecht University; representation; data; contrast; representation; data; papers; data structure; grid; challenges; counterparts; approaches; modeling languages; PCRaster; languages; GIS; processes; languages; models; models; simulations; time; state; model; time t; function; state; time step; t.; applications; extensions; languages; support; dimensions; world; 3D; inclusion; Monte Carlo simulation techniques; input errors; output; model; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e40c021588 1 16----Presentation----#text.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	commiss:2 wish:1 informati:1 novemb:1 free:1 help:2 univers:3 contributor:1 realiz:1 delft:1 live:1 final:1 geo:2 support:1 dai:2 cost:1 seminar:5 inform:2 geodet:2 gi:2 discuss:1 gin:1 comput:2 fran:1 geometri:1 hope:1 increas:1 der:1 model:1 depart:1 set:1 express:1 schr:1 thank:2 grate:1 collabor:1 scienc:1 netherland:2 held:1 nederland:1 speaker:1 particip:2 sponsor:2 technolog:2 section:1 main:1 organ:1 subcommitte:1 utrecht:2 public:3	||	The seminar day was organized by the Subcommittee Geo-Information Models of the Netherlands Geodetic Commission, and was held at Utrecht University on November 14, 2005. We wish to thank the sponsors of the seminar as well for helping to make the day free of costs for all participants. These sponsors are the Netherlands Geodetic Commission, Geo Informatie Nederland (GIN), the Department of Information and Computing Sciences of Utrecht University, and the section GIS technology at the Delft University of Technology. 4f8e5b80e80eb0e454081588 1 2----Bio----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	acquir:1 phd:1 illinoi:1 integr:1 qualcomm:1 visit:1 analog:1 bs:1 mellon:1 electr:1 faculti:1 xu:1 stanford:1 prior:1 semiconductor:1 eletr:1 inc:2 lucent:1 univers:3 interest:1 iit:1 barcelona:1 shanghai:2 china:1 work:1 cellular:1 yang:1 carnegi:1 assist:2 embed:1 degre:1 bell:1 fudan:1 wave:1 professor:2 comput:1 vlsi:1 senior:1 gp:1 depart:2 engin:3 signal:1 cmo:1 rf:1 corp:2 spring:1 lab:1 newav:1 ic:1 staff:1 cad:1 area:1 electron:1 methodolog:1 current:1 semest:1 institut:1 member:1 mm:1 technic:2 speed:1 ms:1 receiv:2 join:1 expertis:1 technolog:3 research:2 process:1 transceiv:1 intern:1 summer:2 macromodel:1 devic:1 respect:1 design:3	||	Yang Xu is currently an assistant professor in the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in Illinois Institute of Technology. He received his Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University in 2005, and the M.S. and B.S. degrees in Electronics Engineering from Fudan University, Shanghai, China in 1999 and 1997, respectively. He was a visiting Assistant Professor in the department of Eletrical Engineering at Stanford University in 2010 Spring semester. Prior to joining the faculty at IIT, he was a senior researcher with Qualcomm Inc. where he worked on embedded GPS receiver and 3G cellular transceiver designs. From 1999 to 2000, he was the member of technical staff at the Bell Labs, Lucent Technologies in Shanghai. He interned in the Barcelona Design Corp. in the summer of 2003 and the Newave Semiconductor Corp. (acquired by Integrated Device Technology Inc.) in the summer of 1998. His technical expertise and research interests are in the areas of CMOS analog and RF/mm-wave IC design, CAD methodology and macromodeling for VLSI, and high speed signal processing.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Electrical and Computer Engineering in Illinois Institute of Technology; Carnegie Mellon University; B.S.; Fudan University; Eletrical Engineering; Stanford University; IIT; Qualcomm Inc.; Bell Labs; Lucent Technologies; Barcelona Design Corp.; Newave Semiconductor Corp.; Integrated Device Technology Inc.; CAD; VLSI; 	PERSON: Yang Xu; 	DATE: 2005; 1999; 1997; 2010; 1999; 2000; 2003; 1998; 	LOCATION: M.S.; Shanghai; China; Shanghai; 	NOUN: Yang Xu; professor; department; Computer Engineering; Illinois Institute; Technology; Ph.D.; Carnegie Mellon University; M.S.; B.S. degrees; Electronics Engineering; Fudan University; Shanghai; China; Assistant Professor; department; Eletrical Engineering; Stanford University; Spring semester; faculty; IIT; researcher; Qualcomm Inc.; GPS receiver; 3G; transceiver designs; member; staff; Bell Labs; Lucent Technologies; Shanghai; Barcelona Design Corp.; summer; Newave Semiconductor Corp.; Integrated Device Technology Inc.; summer; expertise; research interests; areas; CMOS analog; RF\/mm-wave IC design; CAD methodology; macromodeling; VLSI; speed signal processing; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d9011588 2 9----Bio----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	georg:1 queensland:1 illinoi:2 depart:2 appoint:2 mater:1 engin:2 perform:1 scientist:1 electr:1 urbana:1 center:1 champaign:1 alma:1 univers:3 honorari:1 ann:1 serv:1 fisher:1 institut:1 chief:1 scienc:3 coordin:2 joint:1 includ:1 previous:1 trust:1 hold:2 director:2 sever:1 inform:1 reliabl:1 australia:1 iyer:2 professor:2 laboratori:2 distinguish:1 comput:3 csl:1	||	Professor Iyer is the George and Ann Fisher Distinguished Professor of Engineering at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He holds joint appointments in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, the Coordinated Science Laboratory (CSL) and the Department of Computer Science. He also serves as Director of the Center for Reliable and High-Performance Computing at Illinois and as Chief Scientist of the Information Trust Institute. Previously, he was the Director of the Coordinated Science Laboratory. Iyer holds honorary appointments at several Universities including his alma mater the University of Queensland in Australia.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Coordinated Science Laboratory; Department of Computer Science; Center for Reliable; High-Performance Computing; Information Trust Institute; Coordinated Science Laboratory; University of Queensland; 	PERSON: Iyer; George; Ann Fisher; 	LOCATION: Illinois; Australia; 	NOUN: Professor Iyer; George; Ann Fisher Distinguished Professor; Engineering; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; appointments; Department; Computer Engineering; Coordinated Science Laboratory; CSL; Department; Computer Science; Director; Center; Reliable; High-Performance Computing; Illinois; Chief Scientist; Information Trust Institute; Director; Coordinated Science Laboratory; Iyer; appointments; Universities; mater; University; Queensland; Australia; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d9011588 2 10----Bio----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	acquir:1 illinoi:1 phd:1 nasa:1 govern:1 lead:1 tier:1 industri:2 close:1 center:1 illiac:1 contribut:1 requir:1 student:3 univers:2 rang:1 fund:1 doubl:1 support:1 gone:1 wide:1 director:1 startup:1 project:3 inform:1 co:1 system:1 advanc:2 program:1 reliabl:1 tenur:1 iyer:1 multi:1 comput:3 posit:1 valid:1 creation:1 hundr:1 aerospac:1 adapt:1 expenditur:1 applic:1 prof:1 author:2 current:1 graduat:1 develop:1 institut:1 major:3 top:1 includ:1 leadership:1 trust:2 depend:2 vendor:1 excel:1 research:2 master:1 sever:2 secur:1 led:2 architectur:1 larg:1 darpa:1 awar:1 laboratori:2 csl:1 public:1 refere:1 success:3 design:1 found:1	||	Prof Iyer s research contributions have led to major advances in the design and validation of dependable computing systems. He has authored or co-authored close to three hundred refereed publications, graduated over 35 PhD students and many Masters students. His students have gone on to successful leadership positions at major industrial laboratories, top tier Universities and founded several successful startups acquired by major vendors. He has led several large successful projects including the NASA s Center for Excellence in Aerospace Computing, DARPA multi-university program in advanced reliable computing and the creation of the Information Trust Institute. During his tenure as Director of CSL the research expenditures in the laboratory more than doubled. He currently leads the Trusted Illiac project at Illinois. Funded by both industry and government, the project is developing adaptive, application-aware architectures for supporting a wide range of dependability and security requirements.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: NASA; Center for Excellence in Aerospace Computing; DARPA; Information Trust Institute; CSL; 	PERSON: Iyer; 	LOCATION: Illinois; 	NOUN: Prof Iyer; research contributions; advances; design; validation; computing systems; publications; PhD students; Masters students; students; leadership positions; laboratories; tier Universities; startups; vendors; projects; NASA; Center; Excellence; Aerospace Computing; DARPA; program; computing; creation; Information Trust Institute; tenure; Director; CSL; research; laboratory; Illiac project; Illinois; industry; government; project; architectures; range; dependability; security requirements; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d9011588 2 13----Bio----#text.P.SPAN.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	aiaa:1 pioneer:1 award:6 scientist:1 foundat:1 doctor:1 causa:1 contribut:6 toulous:2 toward:1 univers:1 interest:1 recipi:1 joint:1 far:1 recognit:1 sigsac:1 inform:1 degre:1 system:4 ieee:2 machineri:1 advanc:1 reliabl:1 iyer:2 professor:2 distinguish:1 comput:5 fellow:1 emanuel:1 honari:1 medal:1 senior:1 longstand:1 valid:1 aerospac:1 laa:1 recent:1 sabati:1 reach:1 associ:2 american:1 franc:1 scienc:1 outstand:2 includ:1 acm:2 depend:3 fundament:3 audit:1 cnr:1 excel:1 receiv:1 evalu:2 teach:1 research:3 sever:1 secur:2 special:1 measur:1 humboldt:1 group:1 design:2 pior:1	||	Professor Iyer is a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the IEEE, and the ACM. He has received several awards, including the Humboldt Foundation Senior Distinguished Scientist Award for excellence in research and teaching, the AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal for fundamental and pioneering contributions towards the design, evaluation, and validation of dependable aerospace computing systems, and the IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award for fundamental contributions to measurement, evaluation, and design of reliable computing systems. Professor Iyer is also the recipient of the degree of Doctor Honaris Causa from France s Sabatier University of Toulouse in recognition of his outstanding research contributions in dependable computing and for longstanding contributions to joint research LAAS/CNRS in Toulouse. He was recently awarded the 2011 Outstanding Contributions award by the Association of Computing Machinery (ACM)- Special Interest Group on Security and Audit (SIGSAC) for fundamental and far-reaching contributions in secure and dependable computing systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: American Association for the Advancement of Science; Humboldt Foundation; AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal; Sabatier University of Toulouse; Association of Computing Machinery; 	PERSON: Iyer; Emanuel R. 4f8e5b6be80eb0e4d9011588 3 2----Bio----#text.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	aiaa:2 phd:1 nasa:1 xi:1 astronaut:1 foundat:1 urbana:1 stanford:1 center:2 given:1 interest:1 autom:1 ibm:1 hold:1 feder:1 director:1 present:1 ieee:3 system:3 iyer:1 professor:1 fellow:2 posit:1 committe:3 critic:1 depart:1 engin:2 applic:1 associ:1 sigma:1 american:1 publish:1 institut:2 scienc:2 toler:2 softwar:1 invit:1 held:1 technic:2 fundament:1 receiv:2 excel:2 fault:2 technolog:1 research:4 visitor:1 process:1 chair:2 keynot:1 norwegian:1 archiv:1 aeronaut:1 intern:1 humboldt:1 design:2 illinoi:2 zurich:1 pioneer:1 award:3 perform:1 electr:2 confer:2 contribut:1 toward:1 univers:3 honorari:1 coordin:1 joint:1 ber:1 inform:2 co:1 reliabl:2 program:1 australia:1 distinguish:1 comput:11 volum:1 medal:1 senior:1 valid:1 queensland:1 aerospac:3 appoint:1 recent:1 journal:1 champaign:1 area:1 societi:2 extens:1 mem:1 ifip:2 acm:1 depend:2 edit:1 evalu:2 teach:1 sever:1 laboratori:3 measur:1 refere:1 ravishankar:1	||	Ravishankar K. Iyer	##true@@false$$	holds a joint appointment as professor in the departments of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Computer Science, and the Coordinated Science Laboratory at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also co-director of the Center for Reliable and High-Performance Computing and the Illinois Computing Laboratory for Aerospace Systems and Software -- a NASA Center for Excellence in Aerospace Computing. Iyer's research interests are in the area of reliable computing, measurement and evaluation, and automated design. He received his Ph.D. in electrical engineering from Queensland University in Australia and has held positions at the Norwegian Institute of Technology, Stanford University, and the IBM Research Laboratories in Zurich. He is an IEEE Computer Society distinguished visitor, an associate fellow of the American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA), a fellow of the IEEE, and a mem- ber of ACM and the Sigma Xi honorary research society. He has published extensively in archival journals and refereed conferences; recently, he edited an International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) volume on dependable computing for critical applications. He has chaired several conferences and program committees and given invited and keynote presentations. He is on the IFIP Technical Committee on Fault-Tolerant Computing and chairs the IEEE Technical Committee on Fault-Tolerant Computing. In 1991, he received the Senior Humboldt Foundation Award for excellence in research and teaching and in 1993 was awarded the AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal for "fundamental and pioneering contributions toward the design, evaluation, and validation of dependable aerospace computing systems."	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Electrical and Computer Engineering; Computer Science; Coordinated Science Laboratory; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Center for Reliable; Illinois Computing Laboratory for Aerospace Systems; NASA Center for Excellence in Aerospace Computing; Queensland University; Norwegian Institute of Technology; Stanford University; IBM Research Laboratories; IEEE Computer Society; American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics; AIAA; International Federation for Information Processing; IFIP Technical Committee on Fault-Tolerant Computing; IEEE Technical Committee on Fault-Tolerant Computing; Senior Humboldt Foundation; AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal; 	PERSON: Ravishankar K. Iyer; 	DATE: 1991; 1993; 	LOCATION: Australia; Zurich; 	NOUN: Ravishankar K. 4f8e5b6ae80eb0e419011588 3 5----Bio----#text.SPAN.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.FORM.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 hall:1 teng:1 neural:2 electr:3 bs:1 univers:2 dean:1 colleg:3 fuzzi:2 control:2 sm:1 textbook:1 scientif:1 learn:1 prentic:1 tung:1 ct:1 nation:1 degre:2 ieee:1 system:2 transact:1 professor:1 hsinchu:1 comput:2 depart:1 structur:1 paper:2 engin:4 usa:1 lifelong:1 journal:1 author:1 nctu:3 august:1 msee:1 serv:1 publish:1 scienc:2 dr:3 includ:1 purdu:1 taiwan:1 chin:1 lin:3 paramet:1 provost:1 receiv:1 chair:1 respect:1 world:1 chiao:1 found:1	||	Dr. Chin-Teng (CT) Lin (S 88-M 91-SM 99-F 05) received B.S. degree in control engineering from National Chiao-Tung University (NCTU), Hsinchu, Taiwan in 1986 and the M.S.E.E. and Ph.D. degrees in electrical engineering from Purdue University, U.S.A., in 1989 and 1992, respectively. Since August 1992, he has been with the College of Electrical Engineering and the College of Computer Science, NCTU, where he is the Provost and the Lifelong Chair Professor of the Department of Electrical Engineering. Dr. Lin served as the Founding Dean of Computer Science College of NCTU from 2005 to 2007. He is the textbook author of Neural Fuzzy Systems (Prentice Hall) and Neural Fuzzy Control Systems with Structure and Parameter Learning (World Scientific). Dr. Lin has published over 165 journal papers, including about 77 IEEE transaction papers.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: National Chiao-Tung University; Purdue University; College of Electrical Engineering; College of Computer Science; Department of Electrical Engineering; Founding Dean of Computer Science College of NCTU; Prentice Hall; Neural Fuzzy Control Systems; 	PERSON: Dr. Chin-Teng; Dr. Lin; Dr. Lin; 	DATE: 1986; 1989; 1992; 1992; 2005; 2007; 	LOCATION: B.S.; Hsinchu; Taiwan; U.S.A.; 	NOUN: Dr. Chin-Teng; CT; Lin; S 88-M 91-SM; B.S. degree; control engineering; National Chiao-Tung University; NCTU; Hsinchu; Taiwan; M.S.E.E.; Ph.D. degrees; engineering; Purdue University; U.S.A.; August; College; Engineering; College; Computer Science; NCTU; Provost; Lifelong Chair Professor; Department; Engineering; Dr. Lin; Dean; Computer Science College; NCTU; textbook author; Neural Fuzzy Systems; Prentice Hall; Fuzzy Control Systems; Structure; Parameter Learning; World Scientific; Dr. Lin; journal papers; IEEE transaction papers; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e419011588 0 22----Award----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	gener:1 intellig:2 award:1 neural:1 neuro:1 council:1 level:3 basic:1 rang:1 circuitri:1 brain:2 fuzzi:1 cognit:1 career:1 pursuit:1 nation:1 goal:1 present:1 inform:1 ieee:1 system:5 machin:1 view:1 axi:1 paper:2 engin:2 signal:1 build:1 network:1 algorithm:1 short:1 journal:2 area:1 develop:3 won:1 publish:1 scienc:1 dr:1 softwar:1 includ:2 outstand:1 taiwan:1 lin:1 biolog:2 research:3 main:1 point:1 multimedia:1 term:2 take:1 interfac:1 target:1 inspir:1 hardwar:1 devic:1 design:1	||	He has won the Outstanding Research Award from Taiwan s National Science Council from 1997 to the present. The main axis in Dr. Lin s research career has been the pursuit of biologically inspired intelligent systems, including algorithm development and system design. The research range takes him from the basic circuitry level, through the signal and information level, to the system level and is generated and developed from both the biological and engineering point of views. The short-term target is to develop a brain machine interface and the long-term goal is to build a device with a brain-like intelligent system. He has published more than 120 journal papers in the areas of neural networks, fuzzy systems, multimedia hardware/software and cognitive neuro-engineering, including more than 80 IEEE journal papers.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Outstanding Research Award; National Science Council; 	PERSON: Dr. Lin; 	DATE: 1997; 	LOCATION: Taiwan; 	NOUN: Research Award; Taiwan; National Science Council; axis; Dr. Lin; research career; pursuit; systems; algorithm development; system design; research range; circuitry level; signal; information level; system level; engineering point; views; target; brain machine interface; goal; device; system; journal papers; areas; networks; systems; multimedia hardware\/software; neuro-engineering; IEEE journal papers; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b6be80eb0e4c5011588 1 2----Bio----#text.DIV.SPAN.BODY.HTML.#document	energi:1 michel:1 informazion:1 phd:1 constrain:1 attend:1 dipartimento:1 cours:1 perform:1 electr:1 faculti:2 novemb:1 ferrara:1 sensor:1 center:1 univers:4 interest:1 year:2 decemb:1 milano:1 laurea:1 multipl:1 california:1 mobil:3 random:1 politecnico:1 present:1 padova:2 degre:1 inform:1 system:1 san:1 leav:1 professor:1 commun:3 elettronica:1 born:1 depart:1 engin:3 becam:1 network:3 hoc:1 wireless:2 di:2 venic:1 graduat:1 zorzi:1 diego:1 protocol:1 includ:1 receiv:1 evalu:1 join:2 access:3 research:2 itali:4 spend:1 ucsd:2 academ:1 school:1 broadband:1 ad:1 radio:2 respect:1	||	Michele Zorzi	##true@@false$$	was born in Venice, Italy, on December 6th, 1966. He received the Laurea Degree and the Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from the University of Padova, Italy, in 1990 and 1994, respectively. During the Academic Year 1992/93, he was on leave at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD), attending graduate courses and doing research on multiple access in mobile radio networks. In 1993, he joined the faculty of the Dipartimento di Elettronica e Informazione, Politecnico di Milano, Italy. After spending three years with the Center for Wireless Communications at UCSD, in 1998 he joined the School of Engineering of the University of Ferrara, Italy, where he became a Professor in 2000. Since November 2003, he has been on the faculty at the Information Engineering Department of the University of Padova. His present research interests include performance evaluation in mobile communications systems, random access in mobile radio networks, ad hoc and sensor networks, energy constrained communications protocols, and broadband wireless access.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Padova; University of California; UCSD; Dipartimento di Elettronica; Informazione; Center for Wireless Communications; UCSD; University of Ferrara; Information Engineering Department of the University of Padova; 	PERSON: Michele Zorzi; 	DATE: 1966; 1990; 1994; 1993; 1998; 2000; 2003; 	LOCATION: Venice; Italy; Italy; San Diego; Politecnico di Milano; Italy; Italy; 	NOUN: Michele Zorzi; Venice; Italy; December; Laurea Degree; Ph.D.; Engineering; University; Padova; Italy; Academic Year; leave; University; California; San Diego; UCSD; courses; research; access; radio networks; faculty; Dipartimento di Elettronica; Informazione; Politecnico di Milano; Italy; years; Center; Wireless Communications; UCSD; School; Engineering; University; Ferrara; Italy; Professor; November; faculty; Information Engineering Department; University; Padova; research interests; performance evaluation; communications systems; access; radio networks; ad; sensor networks; energy; communications protocols; broadband; access; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6be80eb0e4c5011588 1 3----Bio----#text.P.DIV.SPAN.BODY.HTML.#document	energi:1 person:2 issu:1 network:3 journal:3 mai:1 wireless:5 wilei:1 area:1 current:1 serv:1 publish:1 chief:2 zorzi:1 dr:1 acm:1 select:1 manag:1 mobil:1 ursi:1 jun:1 kluwer:1 board:1 system:1 editori:1 ieee:6 editor:3 underwat:1 transact:2 multi:1 radio:1 commun:8 comput:1 guest:1 special:1 fellow:1 magazin:2 media:1	||	Dr. Zorzi was the Editor-In-Chief of the IEEE Wireless Communications Magazine in 2003--2005, is currently the Editor-In-Chief of the IEEE Transactions on Communications, and serves on the Editorial Boards of the IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, the Wiley Journal of Wireless Communications and Mobile Computing and the ACM/URSI/Kluwer Journal of Wireless Networks. He was also guest editor for special issues in the IEEE Personal Communications Magazine ("Energy Management in Personal Communications Systems," Jun. 1998) and the IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications ("Multi-media Network Radios," May 1999, and "Underwater Wireless Communications and Networks," to be published in 2008). He is a Fellow of the IEEE.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: IEEE Wireless Communications Magazine; IEEE Transactions on Communications; Wireless Communications; Wiley Journal of Wireless Communications; ACM\/URSI\/Kluwer Journal of Wireless Networks; 	PERSON: Dr. Zorzi; 	DATE: 2003; 2005; 1998; 1999; 2008; 	NOUN: Dr. Zorzi; Editor-In-Chief; IEEE Wireless Communications Magazine; Editor-In-Chief; IEEE Transactions; Communications; Editorial Boards; IEEE Transactions; Wireless Communications; Wiley Journal; Wireless Communications; Mobile Computing; ACM\/URSI\/Kluwer Journal; Wireless Networks; editor; issues; IEEE Personal Communications Magazine; Energy Management; Personal Communications Systems; Jun.; IEEE Journal; Selected Areas; Communications; Network Radios; May; Wireless Communications; Networks; Fellow; IEEE; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b82e80eb0e40b0a1588 4 2----Bio----#text.SPAN.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	postdoctor:1 cheng:1 etc:2 intellig:2 patent:1 juli:1 pakdd:2 confer:2 cover:1 sigkdd:1 refer:1 univers:2 file:1 interest:1 relat:1 varieti:1 california:1 mobil:1 number:2 wide:1 discoveri:1 board:1 director:1 databas:2 nation:1 inform:1 co:1 system:1 editor:1 ieee:2 roc:1 transact:2 program:2 ci:1 professor:1 distinguish:1 comput:3 fellow:1 cikm:1 committe:1 biomed:1 medic:1 icdm:1 artifici:1 vice:1 depart:1 paper:1 knowledg:2 engin:2 data:4 vincent:1 usa:2 ncku:3 journal:2 chapter:1 associ:1 presid:1 prestigi:1 icd:1 august:1 serv:1 mine:2 publish:1 institut:1 scienc:2 dr:1 member:1 held:1 taiwanes:1 includ:2 acm:1 taiwan:1 tseng:2 kung:1 web:1 join:1 technolog:1 research:3 tainan:1 chair:3 informat:2 multimedia:1 intern:2 premier:1 divis:1 berkelei:1	||	Vincent S. Tseng is distinguished professor at Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU), Taiwan. He is also the president of Taiwanese Association for Artificial Intelligence and Vice Chair for IEEE CIS Tainan Chapter. Before joining NCKU, he was a postdoctoral research fellow in Computer Science Division of University of California at Berkeley, USA during 1998 and 1999. He was also the director for Institute of Medical Informatics of NCKU during August 2008 and July 2011. Dr. Tseng has a wide variety of research interests covering data mining, intelligent computing, mobile and Web technologies, biomedical informatics and multimedia databases. He has published more than 250 research papers in referred journals and international conferences with more than 15 patents in USA and ROC held/filed. He is on the editor board of a number of prestigious journals, including IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering, ACM Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data, etc. He has served as chairs/program committee members for a number of premier international conferences related to data mining and database systems, including SIGKDD, ICDM,ICDE,CIKM,PAKDD,etc. He is also the Program Co-Chair for PAKDD 2013.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering; National Cheng Kung University; NCKU; Taiwanese Association for Artificial Intelligence; NCKU; Computer Science Division of University of California; Institute of Medical Informatics of NCKU; Data Engineering; ICDM; CIKM; 	PERSON: Vincent S. He most recently served as the CEO of WebCast Technologies from 2000 to 2002. He served as the Director of R&D for Optivision from 1998 to 2000. Weiping's education career preceded his commercial career when he joined the Faculty at Lehigh University as an Assistant Professor in 1987. He was promoted to Associate Professor with Tenure in 1993. He was promoted to Full Professor in 1998. He received his Ph.D. and M.S. degrees from Stanford University in 1988 and 1983 respectively, and his B.S. degree from the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) in 1982, all in electrical engineering.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Amity Systems; AVS; WebCast Technologies; Lehigh University; M.S.; Stanford University; B.S.; University of Science and Technology of China; 	DATE: 2000; 2002; 1998; 2000; 1987; 1993; 1998; 1988; 1983; 1982; 	NOUN: group; Amity Systems; patent; algorithms; optimization; video technologies; H.; H.; AVS; network multimedia solution; CEO; WebCast Technologies; Director; R&D; Optivision; Weiping; education career; career; Faculty; Lehigh University; Assistant Professor; Associate Professor; Tenure; Professor; Ph.D.; M.S. degrees; Stanford University; B.S. degree; University; Science; Technology; China; USTC; engineering; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e416011588 2 4----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	manipul:1 via:1 distribut:2 higher:1 languag:5 type:3 ambient:1 foundat:1 biologi:1 function:1 stochast:1 earliest:1 oper:1 martin:1 interest:2 experiment:1 focus:1 year:1 calculu:1 whose:1 mobil:1 vote:1 global:1 molecular:1 script:1 logic:1 system:3 editor:1 program:1 popular:1 influenti:1 protract:1 comput:2 committe:1 compil:1 result:1 model:2 indirectli:1 concurr:1 paper:1 object:2 activ:1 recent:2 applic:2 network:1 polyphon:1 order:1 abadi:1 incarn:1 extens:1 semant:3 current:1 implement:2 theoret:1 ml:1 caml:1 direct:1 member:1 includ:1 spatial:1 obliq:1 modula:1 later:1 establish:1 biolog:1 research:1 main:1 popl:1 orient:1 led:1 interfac:1 book:1 theori:3 user:1 design:3	||	His main interests are in type theory and operational semantics (for applications to language design, semantics, and implementation), and in concurrency theory (for applications to computer networks and to modeling biological systems). He implemented the first compiler for	##false@@false$$	ML	##false@@true$$	(one of the most popular typed functional language, whose recent incarnations are	##false@@false$$	Caml	##false@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	F#	##false@@true$$	) and one of the earliest direct-manipulation	##false@@false$$	user-interface editors	##false@@true$$	. He was a member of the	##false@@false$$	Modula-3	##false@@true$$	design committee, and has designed a few experimental languages, including	##false@@false$$	Obliq	##false@@true$$	: a distributed higher-order scripting language (voted most influential POPL'95 paper 10 years later), and	##false@@false$$	Polyphonic C#	##false@@true$$	, a distributed extension of C#. His more protracted research activity has been in establishing the semantic and type-theoretic foundations of object-oriented languages, resulting in the 1996 book "	##false@@false$$	A Theory of Objects	##false@@true$$	" with Martin Abadi. More recently he has focused on modeling global and mobile computation, via the	##false@@false$$	Ambient Calculus	##false@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	Spatial Logics	##false@@true$$	, which indirectly led to a current interest in	##false@@false$$	Systems Biology	##false@@true$$	Molecular Programming	##false@@true$$	, and stochastic systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Martin Abadi; Spatial Logics; Systems Biology Molecular Programming; 	DATE: 1996; 	NOUN: interests; type theory; semantics; applications; language design; semantics; implementation; concurrency theory; applications; computer networks; modeling; systems; compiler; ML; language; incarnations; Caml; F; direct-manipulation user-interface editors; member; Modula-3 design committee; languages; Obliq; scripting language; POPL; paper; years; Polyphonic C; extension; C; research activity; foundations; languages; book; Theory; Objects; Martin Abadi; modeling; computation; Calculus; Logics; interest; Systems Biology; Programming; systems; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e416011588 2 21----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	understand:1 concurr:2 denot:1 distribut:1 languag:2 type:2 activ:1 distinct:1 center:1 area:1 oper:1 semant:1 thread:1 overlap:1 research:1 logic:1 around:1 main:1 system:1 aspect:1 program:2 intersect:1 interfac:1 theori:2 user:1 compil:1	||	There are many intersecting and overlapping threads to Cardelli's research: denotational and operational semantics, concurrency, type theory, logic, compilers, and user interfaces. However, these all center around understanding aspects of programming languages. There are two main distinct areas of activity: from 82 to 96 in programming languages and type theory, and from 93 on in distributed systems and concurrency.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Cardelli; 	NOUN: threads; Cardelli; research; semantics; concurrency; type theory; logic; compilers; user interfaces; center; aspects; programming languages; areas; activity; programming languages; type theory; systems; concurrency; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e416011588 2 23----Research----#text.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	system:1 subtyp:1 type:1	||	Type Systems with Subtyping	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Type Systems; Subtyping; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e416011588 2 24----Research----#text.A.LI.UL.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	quantif:1 cardelli:1 concept:1 ultim:2 paper:1 pioneer:1 languag:2 subtyp:3 object:2 type:2 necessari:2 introduc:1 modern:1 contrast:1 although:1 adopt:1 relat:1 import:1 develop:1 initi:1 recogn:1 work:1 establish:1 descript:2 mediat:1 number:1 inherit:1 code:1 wide:1 soon:1 flexibl:1 system:1 formal:2 secur:1 orient:2 coauthor:1 focu:1 sound:1 interfac:1 subclass:2 java:2 bound:1	||	Although the initial focus of object-oriented languages was on "code inheritance" and "subclassing", it is now recognized that subtyping is ultimately a more flexible and important concept. Subtyping has been widely adopted by modern object-oriented languages such as Java and C# for mediating the relations between interfaces, in contrast with subclassing. Bounded quantification will soon be introduced both in Java and in C#. Cardelli pioneered the formal description of type systems with subtyping. Such formal descriptions are necessary to establish type soundness, which is ultimately necessary for security. After the first paper, this work was developed with a number of coauthors. [	##false@@false$$	11	##false@@true$$	10	##false@@true$$		||	NOUN: focus; languages; code inheritance; subclassing; subtyping; concept; Subtyping; languages; Java; C; relations; interfaces; contrast; subclassing; quantification; Java; C; Cardelli; description; type systems; subtyping; descriptions; type soundness; security; paper; work; number; coauthors; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e416011588 2 30----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	equip:1 born:1 phd:1 cardelli:1 tool:1 lab:1 microsoft:1 center:1 murrai:1 univers:2 cambridg:1 current:1 pisa:1 head:1 alto:1 scienc:1 work:1 hill:1 uk:1 assum:1 principl:1 research:3 itali:1 luca:1 digit:1 bell:1 system:1 secur:1 edinburgh:1 near:1 term:1 program:1 palo:1 comput:1 montecatini:1 corpor:1 group:1 posit:1 studi:1 princip:1	||	Luca Cardelli was born near	##false@@false$$	Montecatini Terme	##false@@true$$	, Italy, studied at the	##false@@false$$	University of Pisa	##false@@true$$	(until 1978-07-12), and has a Ph.D. in computer science from the	##false@@false$$	University of Edinburgh	##false@@true$$	(1982-04-01). He worked at	##false@@false$$	Bell Labs, Murray Hill	##false@@true$$	, from 1982-04-05 to 1985-09-20, and at Digital Equipment Corporation,	##false@@false$$	Systems Research Center	##false@@true$$	in	##false@@false$$	Palo Alto	##false@@true$$	, from 1985-09-30 to 1997-10-31, before assuming a position on 1997-11-03 at	##false@@false$$	Microsoft Research	##false@@true$$	, in	##false@@false$$	Cambridge UK	##false@@true$$	, where he is currently Principal Researcher and head of the	##false@@false$$	Programming Principles and Tools	##false@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	Security	##false@@true$$	groups.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Pisa; University of Edinburgh; Bell Labs; Digital Equipment Corporation; Systems Research Center; Microsoft Research; Programming Principles and Tools; 	PERSON: Luca Cardelli; Murray Hill; 	LOCATION: Montecatini Terme; Italy; Palo Alto; Cambridge UK; 	NOUN: Luca Cardelli; Montecatini Terme; Italy; University; Pisa; Ph.D.; computer science; University; Edinburgh; Bell Labs; Murray Hill; Digital Equipment Corporation; Systems Research Center; Palo Alto; position; Microsoft Research; Cambridge UK; Principal Researcher; head; Programming Principles; Tools; Security groups; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e416011588 2 31----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	manipul:1 via:1 distribut:2 higher:1 languag:5 type:3 ambient:1 foundat:1 biologi:1 function:1 stochast:1 earliest:1 oper:1 martin:1 interest:2 experiment:1 focus:1 year:1 calculu:1 whose:1 mobil:1 vote:1 global:1 molecular:1 script:1 logic:1 system:3 editor:1 program:1 popular:1 influenti:1 protract:1 comput:2 committe:1 compil:1 result:1 model:2 indirectli:1 concurr:1 paper:1 object:2 activ:1 recent:2 applic:2 network:1 polyphon:1 order:1 abadi:1 incarn:1 extens:1 semant:3 current:1 implement:2 theoret:1 ml:1 caml:1 direct:1 member:1 includ:1 spatial:1 obliq:1 modula:1 later:1 establish:1 biolog:1 research:1 main:1 popl:1 orient:1 led:1 interfac:1 book:1 theori:3 user:1 design:3	||	His main interests are in type theory and operational semantics (for applications to language design, semantics, and implementation), and in concurrency theory (for applications to computer networks and to modeling biological systems). He implemented the first compiler for	##false@@false$$	ML	##false@@true$$	(one of the most popular typed functional language, whose recent incarnations are	##false@@false$$	Caml	##false@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	F#	##false@@true$$	) and one of the earliest direct-manipulation	##false@@false$$	user-interface editors	##false@@true$$	. He was a member of the	##false@@false$$	Modula-3	##false@@true$$	design committee, and has designed a few experimental languages, including	##false@@false$$	Obliq	##false@@true$$	: a distributed higher-order scripting language (voted most influential POPL'95 paper 10 years later), and	##false@@false$$	Polyphonic C#	##false@@true$$	, a distributed extension of C#. His more protracted research activity has been in establishing the semantic and type-theoretic foundations of object-oriented languages, resulting in the 1996 book "	##false@@false$$	A Theory of Objects	##false@@true$$	" with Martin Abadi. More recently he has focused on modeling global and mobile computation, via the	##false@@false$$	Ambient Calculus	##false@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	Spatial Logics	##false@@true$$	, which indirectly led to a current interest in	##false@@false$$	Systems Biology	##false@@true$$	Molecular Programming	##false@@true$$	, and stochastic systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Martin Abadi; Spatial Logics; Systems Biology Molecular Programming; 	DATE: 1996; 	NOUN: interests; type theory; semantics; applications; language design; semantics; implementation; concurrency theory; applications; computer networks; modeling; systems; compiler; ML; language; incarnations; Caml; F; direct-manipulation user-interface editors; member; Modula-3 design committee; languages; Obliq; scripting language; POPL; paper; years; Polyphonic C; extension; C; research activity; foundations; languages; book; Theory; Objects; Martin Abadi; modeling; computation; Calculus; Logics; interest; Systems Biology; Programming; systems; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
