I was an investigator on the MoD-funded	##false@@false$$	SSEI	##false@@true$$	, where I led research on model-driven systems integration. I was also recently an investigator on the FP7 project INESS, where we used model transformation to enable analysis of large-scale (safety) requirements models. I was a co-investigator on a recent EPSRC project exploring domain-specific languages for measurement, for the National Physical Laboratory. I was a partner in the European Integrated Project	##false@@false$$	MODELPLEX	##false@@true$$	, which ran from September 2006 through February 2010. In MODELPLEX, we extended our work on the	##false@@false$$	Epsilon	##false@@true$$	project, which is one of the leading platforms for model management. I was principal investigator on the EPSRC project	##false@@false$$	Refinement Patterns for Contractual Statecharts	##true@@false$$	, which ran from July 2007 until September 2010. I was the principal investigator on the e-Science EPSRC-funded project	##false@@false$$	eXGrid: Agile Development of High-Integrity Grid Middleware	##false@@true$$	, which ran from 2004-2007. I was a Strand Leader ("Model-Based Systems Engineering") in the	##false@@false$$	High-Integrity Real-Time Systems DARP	##false@@true$$	, which was funded by the EPSRC, DTI, and the MOD, in partnership with BAE Systems, Rolls-Royce, and QinetiQ from 2002-2006; some of the DARP work is continuing (particularly on FPTC/failure analysis) and I am involved in supervising this. I was also a partner in the EU Integrated Project	##false@@false$$	MODELWARE	##false@@true$$	, which ran from 2004-2006. As well, I also did some work with QinetiQ in 2005 on a project to compare the benefits of proof versus testing under the auspices of DO-178B.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: EC; National Physical Laboratory; Agile Development of High-Integrity Grid Middleware; DTI; BAE Systems; Rolls-Royce; QinetiQ; DARP; QinetiQ; 	DATE: 2006; 2010; 2007; 2010; 2005; 	LOCATION: INESS; MODELPLEX; MODELPLEX; EU; MODELWARE; 	NOUN: investigator; EC FP7 project; languages; tools; Model-Driven; Systems development; investigator; MoD-funded SSEI; research; systems integration; investigator; FP7 project INESS; model transformation; analysis; safety; requirements models; co-investigator; EPSRC project; languages; measurement; National Physical Laboratory; partner; Integrated Project MODELPLEX; September; February; MODELPLEX; work; Epsilon project; platforms; model management; investigator; EPSRC project Refinement Patterns; Contractual Statecharts; July; September; investigator; e-Science; project eXGrid; Agile Development; High-Integrity Grid Middleware; Strand Leader; Model-Based Systems Engineering; High-Integrity Real-Time Systems DARP; EPSRC; DTI; MOD; partnership; BAE Systems; Rolls-Royce; QinetiQ; DARP work; FPTC\/failure analysis; partner; EU Integrated Project MODELWARE; work; QinetiQ; project; benefits; proof; testing; auspices; DO-178B; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e408091588 2 5----Research----#text.P.BODY.HTML.#document	perspect:1 complex:3 permit:1 higher:2 permut:1 analog:1 object:2 surpris:1 obviou:1 time:1 simplici:3 graph:3 realm:1 basic:1 geometr:1 place:1 work:1 look:1 counterpart:1 turn:1 notion:1 numer:1 extend:1 fundament:1 briefli:1 random:2 come:1 enter:1 combinator:2 us:1 suggest:1 dimens:1 provid:1 inher:1 dimension:4 aspect:1 start:1 discuss:2 plai:1 theori:2 local:1 view:2 geometri:1	||	Geometry provides a very useful perspective on numerous basic aspects of combinatorics. In this view it is not too surprising that a notion of dimension comes into play. As it turns out, many of the most fundamental objects of combinatorics are inherently one-dimensional. This suggests that we look into higher-dimensional counterparts of these objects. The most obvious place to start is with graphs which, viewed geometrically, are one-dimensional simplicial complexes. I will discuss some work on the extending of the theory of random graphs to the realm of random simplicial complexes. I will also discuss higher-dimensional analogs of permutations. If time permits I will also enter briefly into the local theory of graphs and of simplicial complexes.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Geometry; perspective; aspects; combinatorics; view; notion; dimension; play; objects; combinatorics; counterparts; objects; place; graphs; complexes; work; theory; graphs; realm; complexes; analogs; permutations; time; briefly; theory; graphs; complexes; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

519146e0b826b0e4cda51d9c 2 22----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	complex:2 depart:1 structur:2 cours:1 object:3 type:3 network:7 advis:1 real:1 student:1 heterogen:2 univers:1 page:1 social:1 among:1 friendship:1 analysi:1 intertwin:1 form:2 multipl:3 rich:1 homogen:1 semi:1 web:1 togeth:1 provid:1 teach:1 interconnect:1 relationship:2 differ:1 inform:4 often:1 professor:1 exampl:1 studi:1 world:1 reflect:1	||	Objects in the real world are interconnected, often forming complex heterogeneous but semi-structured information networks. Different from some studies on social network analysis where friendship networks or web page networks form homogeneous information networks, heterogeneous information network reflect complex and structured relationships among multiple typed objects. For example, in a university network, objects of multiple types, such as students, professors, courses, departments, and multiple typed relationships, such as teach and advise are intertwined together, providing rich information.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Objects; world; information networks; studies; network analysis; friendship networks; web page networks; information networks; information network; complex; relationships; objects; example; university network; objects; types; students; professors; courses; departments; relationships; information; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$
519146e0b826b0e4cda51d9c 2 23----Research----#text.SPAN.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	integr:2 structur:2 knowledg:1 link:1 promis:1 explor:1 data:2 show:1 uncov:1 network:6 introduc:1 rank:1 heterogen:2 interest:1 methodolog:2 power:2 classif:1 role:1 mine:3 develop:1 analysi:2 direct:1 includ:1 trust:1 semi:1 discoveri:1 research:1 sever:1 present:1 inform:4 larg:1 hidden:1 predict:1 cluster:1 critic:1	||	We explore the power of such semi-structured heterogeneous information network by developing methodologies for mining such networks. We introduce several interesting new data mining methodologies, including integrated ranking and clustering, classification, data integration, trust analysis, role discovery and prediction. We show that structured information networks are informative, and link analysis on such networks is powerful at uncovering critical knowledge hidden in large networks. We also present a few promising research directions on mining heterogeneous information networks.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: power; information network; methodologies; networks; data mining methodologies; clustering; classification; data integration; trust analysis; role discovery; prediction; information networks; link analysis; networks; knowledge; networks; research directions; mining; information networks; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$

519146e0b826b0e4cda51d9c 2 25----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	han:1 daniel:1 illinoi:1 wareh:1 jiawei:1 award:4 drucker:1 faculti:1 urbana:1 confer:4 center:1 popularli:1 wallac:1 sigkdd:1 univers:1 sdm:1 chief:1 coordin:1 vldb:1 textbook:1 support:1 discoveri:1 director:1 databas:1 inform:2 ieee:3 system:1 co:1 editor:1 transact:1 mcdowel:1 program:1 pc:1 professor:1 comput:3 fellow:1 committe:1 icdm:1 armi:1 concept:1 america:1 knowledg:1 data:4 lab:1 network:2 journal:1 champaign:1 societi:2 current:1 serv:1 mine:2 analysi:1 innov:1 bliss:1 scienc:1 technic:1 includ:1 acm:3 receiv:1 us:2 research:3 kdd:1 techniqu:1 uiuc:1 achiev:1 worldwid:1 chair:2 academ:1 book:1 intern:1 public:1 emin:1 found:1	||	Jiawei Han, Bliss Professor of Computer Science, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He has been researching into data mining, information network analysis, database systems, and data warehousing, with over 600 journal and conference publications. He has chaired or served on many program committees of international conferences, including PC co-chair for KDD, SDM, and ICDM conferences, and Americas Coordinator for VLDB conferences. He is currently the founding Editor-In-Chief of ACM Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data and as the Director of Information Network Academic Research Center supported by U.S. Army Research Lab. He is a Fellow of ACM and IEEE, and received 2004 ACM SIGKDD Innovations Award, 2005 IEEE Computer Society Technical Achievement Award, 2009 IEEE Computer Society Wallace McDowell Award, and 2011 Daniel C. Drucker Eminent Faculty Award at UIUC. His book "Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques" has been used popularly as a textbook worldwide.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Bliss Professor of Computer Science; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; KDD; SDM; ICDM; Director of Information Network Academic Research Center; U.S. Army Research Lab; Computer Society Wallace McDowell Award; 	PERSON: Daniel C. Drucker; 	DATE: 2004; 2005; 2009; 2011; 	NOUN: Jiawei Han; Bliss Professor; Computer Science; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; data mining; information network analysis; database systems; data warehousing; journal; conference publications; program committees; conferences; PC co-chair; KDD; SDM; ICDM conferences; Americas Coordinator; VLDB conferences; founding Editor-In-Chief; ACM Transactions; Knowledge Discovery; Data; Director; Information Network Academic Research Center; U.S. Army Research Lab; Fellow; ACM; IEEE; ACM SIGKDD Innovations Award; IEEE Computer Society Technical Achievement Award; IEEE Computer Society Wallace McDowell Award; Daniel C. 4f8e5b82e80eb0e4a5091588 4 6----Presentation----#text.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	mainten:1 benefit:1 gener:1 paradigm:1 servic:2 distribut:1 facilit:1 perform:1 fluctuat:1 scalabl:1 foundat:1 center:2 avoid:1 open:1 barrier:1 cover:1 although:1 adopt:2 busi:1 captur:1 dynam:1 support:1 matur:1 evid:1 respons:1 consist:1 mobil:1 global:1 environ:1 qualiti:1 avail:1 provid:1 architect:1 aim:1 program:1 emerg:1 comput:4 economi:1 lectur:2 provis:1 prefer:1 straightforward:1 novel:1 compat:1 virtual:1 scale:2 model:1 complex:1 infrastructur:1 can:1 next:1 data:4 geograph:1 object:1 issu:1 automat:1 applic:2 risk:1 resourc:2 privaci:1 ultra:1 softwar:2 abstract:1 parallel:1 workload:1 standard:2 task:1 vendor:1 manag:4 lock:1 lazi:1 intens:1 dimens:1 technolog:3 mix:1 differ:1 elast:1 secur:2 address:1 term:3 larg:1 interfac:1 fall:1 intern:1 deliv:1 strategi:1 cloud:3 interact:1 server:1 hardwar:1 part:2 rethink:1 design:1	||	Abstract	##true@@false$$	Could computing is a complex mix of different technologies, novel programming paradigms, resource management strategies, computational and business models. It is emerging as the preferred technology for delivering large scale applications that are both data intensive and interactive, and have to provide high quality service objectives in terms of performance, availability and security. The first part of the lectures aims to cover the foundation technologies for the management of cloud infrastructure, data centers and virtualized environments in terms of data and server management. Although the economies of scale and elasticity of cloud computing facilitate dynamically provision of hardware and software resources in response to any fluctuation in workload, and geographically distributed data centers can support mobility and next generation services, the second part of the lectures evidences that capturing the benefits of global computing is not straightforward. Software architects have to rethink the design of their applications in terms of parallelism, ultra-scalability, lazy consistency. Other barriers to cloud adoption will fall when the adoption of open standards will avoid vendor lock-in risks, when the standardization of interfaces will mature as well as compatibility and automatic management of many maintenance tasks, and security and privacy issues will be addressed at an international dimension.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: computing; mix; technologies; programming paradigms; resource management strategies; business models; technology; scale applications; data; quality service objectives; terms; performance; availability; security; part; aims; foundation technologies; management; cloud infrastructure; data centers; environments; terms; data; server management; economies; scale; elasticity; cloud computing; provision; hardware; software resources; response; fluctuation; workload; data centers; mobility; generation services; part; evidences; benefits; computing; Software architects; design; applications; terms; parallelism; ultra-scalability; consistency; barriers; adoption; adoption; standards; vendor lock-in risks; standardization; interfaces; compatibility; management; maintenance tasks; security; privacy issues; dimension; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

His interests include parallel and distributed systems, networking, wireless and GRID computing. During 1994-1995 he spent 12 months as visiting professor at the Department of Electrical Engineering of Duke University, North Carolina - USA, where he was involved in research on advanced analytical modelling techniques. He is the coordinator of the Ph.D. course in Advanced Technologies for Information Engineering currently available at the University of Messina and the responsible for the course of study in computers and telecommunication engineering. He was a referee for the European Community for the projects of the fourth, fifth and sixth Framework Program.He is currently the responsible for all the ICT and e-learning activities for the University of Messina, the director of the RFIDLab, a joint research lab with Oracle and Intel on RFID and wireless, and the director of the Centre on Information Technologies and Their Applications (CIA).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Messina; Department of Electrical Engineering of Duke University; Advanced Technologies for Information Engineering; University of Messina; European Community; ICT; University of Messina; Oracle; Intel; Centre on Information Technologies; 	PERSON: Antonio Puliafito; 	LOCATION: Italy; North Carolina; USA; 	NOUN: Antonio Puliafito; professor; computer engineering; University; Messina; Italy; interests; parallel; systems; networking; GRID computing; months; professor; Department; Engineering; Duke University; North Carolina; USA; research; modelling techniques; coordinator; Ph.D. course; Advanced Technologies; Information Engineering; University; Messina; course; study; computers; telecommunication engineering; referee; European Community; projects; Framework Program; ICT; e-learning activities; University; Messina; director; RFIDLab; research lab; Oracle; Intel; RFID; director; Centre; Information Technologies; Applications; CIA; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

He holds a Ph.D. in Systems Science, a degree that he got from the	##false@@false$$	Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn	##false@@true$$	(now known as the Polytechnic Institute of New York University). 4f8e5b50e80eb0e480ec1488 2 8----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	call:1 dumai:1 other:1 colleagu:1 someon:1 enough:1 someth:1 microsoft:1 mai:1 author:1 document:2 conduct:1 bellcor:1 search:1 vocabulari:3 varieti:1 choos:1 best:1 find:1 limit:1 work:1 implic:1 describ:2 problem:1 us:2 join:1 technolog:1 research:2 tradit:1 telcordia:1 inform:2 differ:3 peopl:1 term:1 retriev:2 experi:1 method:1 demonstr:1 success:1 studi:1 thing:1	||	Before joining Microsoft in 1997, Dumais was a researcher at Bellcore (now	##false@@false$$	Telcordia Technologies	##false@@true$$	), where she and her colleagues conducted research into what is now called the	##false@@false$$	vocabulary problem	##false@@true$$	in	##false@@false$$	information retrieval	##false@@true$$	Their study demonstrated, through a variety of experiments, that different people use different vocabulary to describe the same thing, and that even choosing the "best" term to describe something is not enough for others to find it. One implication of this work is that because the author of a document may use different vocabulary than someone searching for the document, traditional	##false@@false$$	information retrieval	##false@@true$$	methods will have limited success.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Microsoft; Bellcore; Telcordia Technologies; 	PERSON: Dumais; 	DATE: 1997; 	NOUN: Microsoft; Dumais; researcher; Bellcore; Telcordia Technologies; colleagues; research; vocabulary problem; information retrieval; study; variety; experiments; people; vocabulary; thing; term; something; others; implication; work; author; document; vocabulary; someone; document; information retrieval methods; success; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

4f8e5b50e80eb0e480ec1488 4 22----Others----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	inform:1 tempor:1 retriev:1 titl:1 dynam:1	||	Title: Temporal Dynamics and Information Retrieval	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Temporal Dynamics and Information Retrieval; 	NOUN: Title; Dynamics; Information Retrieval; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b50e80eb0e480ec1488 4 23----Presentation----#text.SPAN.BUTTON.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	need:1 understand:1 gener:1 singl:1 incorpor:2 tool:1 challeng:1 visit:2 time:3 rank:2 search:1 page:1 event:1 dynam:2 final:1 static:1 support:1 describ:1 polici:1 extract:1 digit:1 content:4 peopl:2 present:2 inform:8 system:2 aspect:1 conclud:1 view:1 collect:1 result:2 model:1 tempor:2 engin:1 re:2 prototyp:1 evolut:1 algorithm:1 resourc:1 browser:1 develop:1 calendar:1 talk:1 analys:1 abstract:1 includ:1 implic:1 snapshot:1 manag:2 crawl:1 fulli:1 web:4 evalu:1 intent:1 overview:1 focu:1 pattern:1 address:1 retriev:4 featur:1 influenc:1 core:1 improv:1 interact:2 chang:4 user:1	||	Abstract: Many digital resources, like the Web, are dynamic and ever-changing collections of information. However, most information retrieval tools developed for interacting with Web content, such as browsers and search engines, focus on a single static snapshot of the information. In this talk, I will present analyses of how Web content changes over time, how people re-visit Web pages over time, and how re-visitation patterns are influenced by changes in user intent and content. These results have implications for many aspects of information retrieval and management including crawling policy, ranking and information extraction algorithms, result presentation, and systems evaluation. I will describe a prototype that supports people in understanding how the information they interact with changes over time, and a new retrieval model that incorporates features about the temporal evolution of content to improve core ranking. Finally, I will conclude with an overview of some general challenges that need to be addressed to fully incorporate temporal dynamics in information retrieval and information management systems.	##false@@false$$	View Events Calendar	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: resources; Web; collections; information; information retrieval tools; Web content; browsers; search engines; focus; snapshot; information; talk; analyses; Web content changes; time; people; Web pages; time; patterns; changes; user intent; content; results; implications; aspects; information retrieval; management; policy; information extraction algorithms; presentation; systems evaluation; prototype; people; information; changes; time; retrieval model; features; evolution; content; core ranking; overview; challenges; dynamics; information retrieval; information management systems; View Events Calendar; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

506d45a49ccfb0e4c4dec96d 1 2----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	distribut:3 type:1 sensor:1 ticker:1 search:1 sequenc:1 combin:1 focus:2 dbmss:1 realtim:1 onlin:1 signific:1 xml:1 continu:2 databas:3 tradit:1 inform:1 project:1 queri:2 system:1 traffic:1 professor:2 ongo:1 lot:1 output:1 internet:2 stream:4 model:1 can:1 broad:1 data:13 issu:1 applic:1 real:1 area:3 order:1 mine:1 massiv:1 optim:1 manag:8 keyword:1 theme:2 problem:1 us:1 produc:1 web:2 research:1 main:1 process:1 differ:1 multimedia:1 zsu:1 retriev:2 item:1 feasibl:1 investig:2 financi:1	||	Professor zsu's research area is database systems. He has ongoing projects in three main areas: distributed data management, multimedia databases, and XML management. In the area of distributed data management, Professor zsu focuses on management of massively distributed data with two broad themes. The first is the investigation of stream data management issues. A data stream is a realtime, continuous, ordered sequence of items that are used to model sensor output, Internet traffic, financial tickers and other applications that continuously produce data. There are significant differences between the type of data managed by traditional DBMSs and stream data focusing on query processing and optimization, and mining of stream data. The second theme is Web data management. Internet and the Web make it feasible to put a lot of data online . However, the management of this data is a real problem. He investigates how this data can be retrieved through a combination of database-like querying and information retrieval-like keyword search.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: XML; 	NOUN: Professor zsu; research area; database systems; projects; areas; data management; multimedia databases; XML management; area; data management; Professor; management; data; themes; investigation; stream data management issues; data stream; realtime; sequence; items; sensor output; Internet traffic; tickers; applications; data; differences; type; data; DBMSs; stream data; query processing; optimization; mining; stream data; theme; Web data management; Internet; Web; lot; data online; management; data; problem; data; combination; querying; information; keyword search; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
506d45a49ccfb0e4c4dec96d 1 3----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	store:1 distribut:1 data:3 good:1 document:1 area:1 requir:1 consider:1 focus:1 effici:1 repositori:1 optim:1 standard:1 manag:1 xml:5 web:1 format:1 databas:3 tradit:1 process:1 queri:2 differ:1 encod:1 system:1 zsu:1 emerg:1 professor:1 investig:1 execut:1	||	In the area of XML databases, he is focusing on efficient execution of queries over XML repositories. XML is the emerging standard for storing documents as well as encoding Web data. The management of XML data requires different considerations than the formatted data that traditional database systems are good at. Professor zsu investigates the query processing and optimization over distributed XML databases.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: XML; XML; XML; XML; 	NOUN: area; XML databases; execution; queries; XML repositories; XML; standard; documents; Web data; management; XML data; considerations; data; database systems; Professor zsu; query processing; optimization; XML databases; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The starting point is that one monolithic system is unlikely to provide satisfactory support for multiple data types, requiring the development of an open architecture that seamlessly combines multiple systems, each focused on one media type. With respect to specific research on various media, he is interested in video databases and the management of audio data.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: area; multimedia databases; work; issues; management; media types; point; system; support; data types; development; architecture; systems; media type; respect; research; media; video databases; management; data; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e458091588 1 4----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	call:1 allow:2 store:2 cumbersom:1 disk:1 data:4 tape:1 abl:1 type:1 build:1 industri:1 mostli:1 transport:1 electron:1 varieti:1 scienc:1 backup:1 site:2 topic:1 work:1 transfer:1 physic:1 career:1 dedupl:1 far:1 wide:1 storag:2 breakthrough:1 research:1 much:1 tradit:1 li:1 system:2 archiv:1 remot:2 expens:1 base:1 approach:1 comput:1 method:1 disast:1 design:1 recoveri:1	||	During his career, Li has worked on a wide variety of topics in computer science. His research breakthrough in designing a type of data storage, called deduplication , allowed the industry to build new disk-based storage systems. The new systems are able to store far more backup and archival data than traditional approaches; they also allow for the electronic transfer of data to remote sites for disaster recovery. Before that, such data were mostly stored on tapes that had to be physically transported to remote sites, a much more cumbersome and expensive method.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Li; 	NOUN: career; Li; variety; topics; computer science; research breakthrough; type; data storage; deduplication; industry; storage systems; systems; data; approaches; transfer; data; sites; disaster recovery; data; tapes; sites; method; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b51e80eb0e4f9ed1488 1 2----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 arbor:1 engin:1 chakrabarti:1 electr:1 beij:1 tsinghua:1 krishnendu:1 univers:3 duke:1 kharagpur:1 ann:1 honorari:1 mse:1 institut:1 china:1 softwar:2 member:1 indian:1 receiv:1 technolog:1 tech:1 michigan:1 degre:2 chair:1 school:1 professor:2 comput:1 theori:1 group:1 posit:1 respect:1	||	Krishnendu Chakrabarty received the B. Tech. degree from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, in 1990, and the M.S.E. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, in 1992 and 1995, respectively. He is now Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Duke University. He is also a member of the Chair Professor Group (honorary position) in Software Theory at the School of Software, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Indian Institute of Technology; M.S.E.; University of Michigan; Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Duke University; School of Software; Tsinghua University; 	PERSON: Krishnendu Chakrabarty; Kharagpur; Ann Arbor; 	DATE: 1990; 1992; 1995; 	LOCATION: Beijing; China; 	NOUN: Krishnendu Chakrabarty; B. 4f8e5b51e80eb0e4f9ed1488 1 3----Award----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	integr:1 alexand:1 test:1 paper:1 award:3 self:1 chakrabarti:1 microfluid:1 germani:1 faculti:1 earli:1 foundat:2 network:1 sensor:1 confer:1 naval:1 prof:1 wireless:1 von:1 dna:1 current:1 best:1 scienc:1 recipi:1 fellowship:1 includ:1 career:1 biochip:1 research:3 young:1 nation:1 sever:1 digit:1 assembl:1 project:1 system:1 ieee:1 offic:1 base:1 testabl:1 circuit:2 investig:1 humboldt:2 design:1	||	Prof. Chakrabarty is a recipient of the National Science Foundation Early Faculty (CAREER) award, the Office of Naval Research Young Investigator award, the Humboldt Research Fellowship from the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, Germany, and several best papers awards at IEEE conferences. His current research projects include: testing and design-for-testability of integrated circuits; digital microfluidics and biochips, circuits and systems based on DNA self-assembly, and wireless sensor networks.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: National Science Foundation Early Faculty; Office of Naval Research Young Investigator; Humboldt Research Fellowship; Humboldt Foundation; 	PERSON: Chakrabarty; Alexander; 	LOCATION: Germany; 	NOUN: Prof. Chakrabarty; National Science Foundation Early Faculty; CAREER; award; Office; Naval Research Young Investigator award; Humboldt Research Fellowship; Alexander von Humboldt Foundation; Germany; papers awards; IEEE conferences; research projects; testing; design-for-testability; circuits; microfluidics; biochips; circuits; systems; DNA self-assembly; sensor networks; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b51e80eb0e4f9ed1488 1 4----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	integr:1 test:2 award:2 mcdonald:1 advis:1 jetta:1 univers:2 dean:1 duke:2 recipi:1 chief:1 mentor:2 jsp:1 pratt:1 ieee:9 system:5 editor:3 transact:3 emerg:1 comput:6 distinguish:5 fellow:2 lectur:1 biomed:1 golden:1 engin:2 chakrabarti:2 marion:1 aid:1 applic:1 journal:2 prof:2 japan:1 associ:1 societi:5 electron:1 promot:1 current:1 graduat:1 serv:3 scienc:1 member:1 invit:1 acm:3 speaker:1 ii:1 excel:2 technolog:1 visitor:2 school:2 caper:1 circuit:4 theori:1 core:1 design:2	||	Prof. Chakrabarty is a Fellow of IEEE, a Golden Core Member of the IEEE Computer Society, and a Distinguished Engineer of ACM. He was a 2009 Invitational Fellow of the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS). He is a recipient of the 2008 Duke University Graduate School Dean s Award for excellence in mentoring, and the 2010 Capers and Marion McDonald Award for Excellence in Mentoring and Advising, Pratt School of Engineering, Duke University. He served as a Distinguished Visitor of the IEEE Computer Society during 2005-2007, and as a Distinguished Lecturer of the IEEE Circuits and Systems Society during 2006-2007. Currently he serves as an ACM Distinguished Speaker, as well as a Distinguished Visitor of the IEEE Computer Society for 2010-2012. He is the Editor-in-Chief for IEEE Design & Test of Computers and for ACM Journal on Emerging Technologies in Computing Systems. Prof. Chakrabarty is also an Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems, IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II, and IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems. He serves as an Editor of the Journal of Electronic Testing: Theory and Applications (JETTA).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Computer Society; Promotion of Science; Duke University Graduate School Dean; Marion McDonald Award for Excellence; Pratt School of Engineering; Duke University; IEEE Computer Society; Systems Society; Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems; 	PERSON: Chakrabarty; Chakrabarty; 	DATE: 2009; 2008; 2010; 	LOCATION: Japan; 	NOUN: Prof. Chakrabarty; Fellow; IEEE; Golden Core Member; IEEE Computer Society; Distinguished Engineer; ACM; Invitational Fellow; Japan Society; Promotion; Science; JSPS; Duke University Graduate School Dean; Award; excellence; mentoring; Capers; Marion McDonald Award; Excellence; Mentoring; Advising; Pratt School; Engineering; Duke University; Visitor; IEEE Computer Society; Lecturer; IEEE Circuits; Systems Society; ACM Distinguished Speaker; Visitor; IEEE Computer Society; Editor-in-Chief; IEEE Design; Test; Computers; ACM Journal; Technologies; Computing Systems; Prof. Chakrabarty; Associate Editor; IEEE Transactions; Computer-Aided Design; Integrated Circuits; Systems; IEEE Transactions; Circuits; Systems II; IEEE Transactions; Biomedical Circuits; Systems; Editor; Journal; Electronic Testing; Theory; Applications; JETTA; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b51e80eb0e497ed1488 2 43----Others----#text.LI.P.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	np:1 reason:1 chat:1 scientist:1 abl:1 type:1 notic:1 nevertheless:2 although:1 requir:1 given:1 student:2 impli:2 effici:1 follow:2 decad:1 charact:1 ture:1 answer:4 effort:1 provid:1 much:1 solv:1 machin:1 comput:2 contradict:1 known:1 case:1 logician:1 might:3 result:2 complex:1 hundr:1 lengthi:1 pleas:1 immedi:1 question:3 conveni:1 condit:2 standard:1 us:2 problem:1 hour:1 despit:1 seem:1 sever:1 techniqu:1 eg:2 either:1 offic:1 correctli:1 item:2 necessarili:2 mathematician:1 explan:1	||	E.g., the question: "Does the given Turing Machine correctly solve the following problem? " will not be answered.	##false@@false$$	Please notice that condition 1 above does not necessarily imply condition 2. E.g., the answer to the question "Is P = NP?" could be typed using either 2 or 3 characters; nevertheless, hundreds of mathematicians, logicians, and computer scientists have not been able to provide such an answer despite several decades of efforts. Also, although this might seem to contradict well-known results in computational complexity, item 2 does not necessarily imply item 1. The reason is that the answer to a question might just follow immediately from standard results or techniques, but nevertheless might require a lengthy explanation to be useful to a student. In all such cases, a chat during office hours is much more efficient and convenient, both for the student and for myself.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Turing Machine; NP; 	NOUN: E.g.; question; Turing Machine; problem; condition; condition; E.g.; answer; question; P; NP; characters; hundreds; mathematicians; logicians; computer scientists; answer; decades; efforts; results; complexity; item; item; reason; answer; question; results; techniques; explanation; student; cases; office hours; student; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b51e80eb0e497ed1488 2 46----Others----#text.LI.P.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	idea:1 gener:1 concern:1 good:1 scientist:1 wait:1 repeat:1 therefor:1 everybodi:1 reach:1 student:1 page:3 write:1 read:1 question:2 effici:1 answer:3 track:1 web:3 ineffici:1 provid:2 point:1 comput:1 alreadi:3 ask:1	||	Computer scientists have to be concerned with efficiency. Asking questions for which an answer is already provided in the web pages is inefficient for everybody (for the student, since he has to write the question and wait for an answer, and for me, since I already provided the answer in the web pages, and have to repeat it). Therefore it is in general a good idea to read the web pages. If you reached this point, you are already well on track :-)	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Computer scientists; efficiency; questions; answer; web pages; everybody; student; question; answer; answer; web pages; idea; web pages; point; track; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$

In the last year we ve moved 3 times across the country, ran out of cash, stayed with family and sometimes we even slept on the floor. In retrospect, had we known what we had to sacrifice as a family we may never have even started. Many couples that go through what went through don t make it. The fact that we got this far is a testament to my amazing wife. For 99% of people the best thing to do is to provide for your family and enjoy your life. If you re in a spot like I was during Techstars, then my suggestion is that you have to basically be Superman. If you really want something than you just have to go for it. Model people who have accomplished extraordinary things, start building real relationships with good people. Work harder, do more faster, and offer to the world as much value as you can. Don t expect overnight success. Just build everyday more than the day before.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Techstars; 	NOUN: family; conversation; wife; something; company; year; times; country; cash; family; floor; retrospect; family; couples; t; fact; testament; wife; %; people; thing; family; life; spot; Techstars; suggestion; Superman; something; Model people; things; relationships; people; Work; offer; world; value; Don t; success; day; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Not being able to build a solid team or raise the seed capital needed to take it to the next level, I took a giant leap of faith and decided to look elsewhere to start over with a fresh start. I found myself couch surfing in Boulder Colorado in May 2010 to attend Boulder Startup Week, an annual event meant to introduce people to the Boulder Startup scene, I absolutely fell in love with the beauty of the mountains, the great tech presence, and most importantly the amazing people in the community. Midway through my trip, I called my wife from downtown Pearl St. I told her that I was skipping my return flight in order to find us an apartment and that she needed to start selling everything we owned. Within 3 weeks we sold 85% of our belongings and moved our family to Boulder. As soon as we landed in Boulder, I began my search for amazing people to bring my vision into reality. I went to every tech meet up, networking event, and boulder open coffee club in order to meet people. I met with successful Techstars alums, investors and interviewed dozens of college students and tech folks of all kinds. I formed some amazing relationships. Less than 6 months later I was preparing to leave my family yet again, this time for 4 months, leaving them in a town we just moved to in order to participate in a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity with Techstars NY.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Boulder Startup Week; Boulder Startup; Techstars NY; 	DATE: 2009; 2010; 	LOCATION: Boulder Colorado; Boulder; Boulder; 	NOUN: Immersive Labs; Grand Rapids MI; Jan; computer-vision; screens; furniture manufacturer; team; seed capital; level; leap; faith; start; couch surfing; Boulder Colorado; May; Boulder Startup Week; event; people; Boulder Startup scene; love; beauty; mountains; presence; people; community; Midway; trip; wife; downtown Pearl St.; return flight; order; apartment; everything; weeks; %; belongings; family; Boulder; Boulder; search; people; vision; reality; tech; event; boulder; coffee club; order; people; Techstars alums; investors; dozens; college students; tech folks; kinds; relationships; months; family; time; months; town; order; opportunity; Techstars NY; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He is now the	##false@@false$$	Head	##false@@true$$	and Chair Professor of the Department that has around 800 undergraduate and graduate students. He was the Director of the Computer Engineering Program (for 10 years) that has around 330 undergraduate students, Director of the Master of Science in Information Technology (for 3 years) which has more than 150 graduate students, and Director of the Computer Engineering research Lab. He is/was a member of the University Senate and University Council. In 1999 to 2000 he held visiting professor positions at	##false@@false$$	Stanford University	##false@@true$$	, USA, and the	##false@@false$$	Swiss Federal Institute of Technology	##false@@true$$	, Lausanne, Switzerland. His general area of research is in high-speed wired/wireless networking in which he has published around 300 research publications, received numerous research grants, and graduated more 30 graduate students. In addition, he has frequently consulted for companies and governmental organizations in the USA, Europe and Asia on	##false@@false$$	high-performance Internet routers and switches	##false@@true$$	as well as high-speed wireless LANs. He is a frequent keynote speaker in International Conferences and Forums.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer Science and Engineering; Hong Kong University of Science and Technology; University; Department; Master of Science in Information Technology; Computer Engineering; University Senate; University Council; Stanford University; USA; Swiss Federal Institute of Technology; 	DATE: 1991; 1999; 2000; 	LOCATION: Lausanne; Switzerland; USA; Europe; Asia; 	NOUN: faculty member; Department; Computer Science; Engineering; Hong Kong University; Science; Technology; member; University; Department; Head; Chair Professor; Department; students; Director; Computer Engineering Program; years; students; Director; Master; Science; Information Technology; years; graduate students; Director; Computer Engineering research Lab; member; University Senate; University Council; professor positions; Stanford University; USA; Swiss Federal Institute; Technology; Lausanne; Switzerland; area; research; networking; research publications; research grants; students; addition; companies; organizations; USA; Europe; Asia; Internet routers; LANs; keynote speaker; International Conferences; Forums; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b51e80eb0e4dded1488 0 5----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	hong:1 phd:1 ipp:1 comsoc:1 amongst:1 award:2 kong:1 perform:1 globecom:1 council:1 confer:5 supervis:1 univers:1 chief:1 workshop:5 select:1 mobil:1 board:1 inform:1 hinet:1 editor:3 editori:1 ieee:11 system:1 transact:1 program:1 commun:7 comput:3 magazin:4 committe:3 vice:1 paper:2 switch:1 activ:1 issu:1 transmiss:1 network:5 journal:2 prof:1 wireless:1 area:1 icc:2 prestigi:1 societi:1 hamdi:1 best:2 member:1 parallel:1 includ:2 technic:3 speed:1 variou:1 receiv:1 access:2 rout:1 chair:3 intern:5 guest:3 special:1 optic:4	||	Prof. Hamdi is/was on the Editorial Board of various prestigious journals and magazines including IEEE Transactions on Communications, IEEE Communication Magazine, Computer Networks, Wireless Communications and Mobile Computing, and Parallel Computing as well as a guest editor of IEEE Communications Magazine, guest editor-in-chief of two special issues of IEEE Journal on Selected Areas of Communications, and a guest editor of Optical Networks Magazine. He has chaired more than 20 international conferences and workshops including The IEEE International High Performance Switching and Routing Conference, the IEEE GLOBECOM/ICC Optical networking workshop, the IEEE ICC High-speed Access Workshop, and the IEEE IPPS HiNets Workshop, and has been on the program committees of more than 200 international conferences and workshops. He was the Chair of IEEE Communications Society Technical Committee on Transmissions, Access and Optical Systems, and Vice-Chair of the Optical Networking Technical Committee, as well as member of the ComSoc technical activities council. He received the best paper award at the IEEE International Conference on Communications in 2009 and the IEEE International Conference on Information and Networking in 1998. He also supervised the best PhD paper award amongst all universities in Hong Kong.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Editorial Board; IEEE Communication Magazine; Computer Networks; Wireless Communications and Mobile Computing; Parallel Computing; Selected Areas of Communications; Optical Networks Magazine; IPPS; Chair of IEEE Communications Society Technical Committee on Transmissions; Optical Systems; Optical Networking Technical Committee; ComSoc technical activities council; IEEE International Conference on Communications; IEEE International Conference on Information and Networking; 	PERSON: Hamdi; 	DATE: 2009; 1998; 	LOCATION: Hong Kong; 	NOUN: Prof. Hamdi; Editorial Board; journals; magazines; IEEE Transactions; Communications; IEEE Communication Magazine; Computer Networks; Wireless Communications; Mobile Computing; Computing; guest editor; IEEE Communications Magazine; guest editor-in-chief; issues; IEEE Journal; Selected Areas; Communications; guest editor; Optical Networks Magazine; conferences; workshops; IEEE International High Performance Switching; Conference; IEEE GLOBECOM\/ICC Optical; workshop; IEEE ICC High-speed Access Workshop; IEEE IPPS HiNets Workshop; program committees; conferences; workshops; Chair; IEEE Communications Society Technical Committee; Transmissions; Access; Optical Systems; Vice-Chair; Optical Networking Technical Committee; member; ComSoc; activities council; paper award; IEEE International Conference; Communications; IEEE International Conference; Information; Networking; PhD paper award; universities; Hong Kong; 	||	##true@@true$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e42c091588 0 6----Bio----#text.SPAN.P.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	complex:1 test:1 engin:1 languag:1 prior:1 author:1 life:1 martin:1 interest:1 davi:1 current:1 institut:1 scienc:2 move:1 elain:2 sigal:1 softwar:4 ron:1 mathemat:1 fault:1 research:3 weyuk:1 co:1 earlier:1 focu:1 courant:1 predict:1 metric:1 book:1 professor:1 comput:3 measur:1 theori:1 fellow:1	||	Elaine Weyuker is an AT&T Fellow doing software engineering research. Prior to moving to AT&T she was a professor of computer science at NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. Her research interests currently focus on software fault prediction, software testing, and software metrics and measurement. In an earlier life, Elaine did research in Theory of Computation and is the co-author of a book "Computability, Complexity, and Languages" with Martin Davis and Ron Sigal.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: AT&T; AT&T; NYU; Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences; 	PERSON: Elaine Weyuker; Elaine; Martin Davis; Ron Sigal; 	NOUN: Elaine Weyuker; AT&T Fellow; software engineering research; AT&T; professor; computer science; NYU; Courant Institute; Mathematical Sciences; research interests; software fault prediction; software testing; software metrics; measurement; life; Elaine; research; Theory; Computation; co-author; book; Computability; Complexity; Languages; Martin Davis; Ron Sigal; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

She is also a member of the US National Academy of Engineering, an IEEE Fellow, and an ACM Fellow and has received IEEE's Harlan Mills Award for outstanding software engineering research, Rutgers University 50th Anniversary Outstanding Alumni Award, and the AT&T Chairman's Diversity Award as well has having been named a Woman of Achievement by the YWCA. She is the chair of the ACM Women's Council (ACM-W) and a member of the Executive Committee of the Coalition to Diversify Computing.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Anita Borg Institute Technical Leadership Award; US National Academy of Engineering; Rutgers University; AT&T; Diversity Award; YWCA; Executive Committee of the Coalition; 	PERSON: Elaine; 	DATE: 2008; 2007; 	NOUN: Elaine; Anita Borg Institute Technical Leadership Award; ACM\/SIGSOFT; Research Award; member; US National Academy; Engineering; IEEE Fellow; ACM Fellow; IEEE; Harlan Mills Award; software engineering research; Rutgers University; Anniversary; Alumni Award; AT&T Chairman; Diversity Award; Woman; Achievement; YWCA; chair; ACM Women; Council; ACM-W; member; Executive Committee; Coalition; Computing; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e42c091588 1 9----Research----#text.SPAN.P.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.FORM.BODY.HTML.#document	characterist:1 neg:1 accomplish:1 model:2 regress:1 next:2 valuabl:1 defect:2 data:1 exposur:1 issu:1 industri:1 expect:1 obvious:1 releas:2 file:2 accur:1 tell:1 year:1 develop:1 softwar:1 lesson:1 histori:1 dealt:1 multipl:1 learn:2 number:2 us:1 code:1 fault:1 like:1 know:1 sever:1 largest:1 field:1 appli:1 system:3 advanc:1 discuss:1 larg:2 predict:3 contain:1 base:1 make:1 success:1 binomi:1 modif:1	||	It would obviously be very valuable to know in advance which files in the next release of a large software system are most likely to contain the largest numbers of defects. To accomplish this, we developed a negative binomial regression model and used it to predict the expected number of defects in each file of the next release of a system. The predictions are based on code characteristics and fault and modification history data. We will discuss what we have learned from applying the model to several large industrial systems, each with multiple years of field exposure, and tell you about our success in making accurate predictions and some of the lessons learned and issues that had to be dealt with.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: advance; release; software system; numbers; defects; regression model; number; defects; file; release; system; predictions; code characteristics; fault; modification history data; model; systems; years; field exposure; success; predictions; lessons; issues; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Her current	##false@@false$$	research	##false@@true$$	focuses on end-user programming, end-user software engineering, information foraging theory as applied to programming, and gender issues in those contexts. 4f8e5b51e80eb0e43fed1488 0 37----Others----#text.LI.UL.BODY.HTML.#document	anyth:1 empir:2 realli:1 manipul:1 cours:4 engin:1 data:1 mainli:1 natur:1 type:1 lab:1 situat:1 cover:1 conduct:1 deal:1 develop:2 coverag:1 end:2 softwar:3 topic:1 control:1 involv:1 research:1 human:1 cs:1 process:1 field:4 focu:1 actual:1 method:1 special:1 case:3 known:1 part:1 studi:7 collect:1 occur:1	||	CS 569: Special topics: Empirical methods for field (case) studies in software engineering	##false@@true$$	. This course deals with the type of empirical study known as the "case" study. These are studies that collect data from natural software development situations as they really occur in the field, in which the researcher does not manipulate or "control" anything. The course is an end-to-end coverage of the process. We will mainly focus on case studies involving human software developers in the field. You will actually conduct a field study as part of this course. The course does not cover lab studies.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: CS; topics; methods; field; case; studies; software engineering; course; type; study; case; study; studies; data; software development situations; field; researcher; control; anything; course; coverage; process; case studies; software developers; field; field study; part; course; course; lab studies; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

He got his academic degrees (Dipl. Inform., Dr.rer.nat., Dr. habil) at Kiel. Since 1991 he is a Full Professor of Applied Informatics at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology - KIT. He is (co-)author of more than 140 publications on advanced algorithms and architectures, in particular on bio-inspired methods in optimisation, algorithms for reconfigurable architectures, and, more recently, on self-organising, adaptive systems. He has been program and conference chair for numerous international workshops and conferences (a.o. RAW, ARCS, IFIP BICC 2006, 2008, ATC 2009, ICAC 2011), is a key member of the Organic Computing Initiative and coordinator of the German priority research program SPP 1183 on Organic Computing . At Karlsruhe, he is the Scientific Spokesperson of the KIT-Focus COMMputation , addressing the scientific challenges implied by the inherent combination of communication and computation.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Karlsruhe Institute of Technology; BICC; ATC; ICAC; Organic Computing Initiative; Karlsruhe; 	PERSON: Hartmut Schmeck; 	DATE: 1991; 2006; 2008; 2009; 2011; 	LOCATION: Kiel; Germany; Waterloo; Canada; Kiel; 	NOUN: Hartmut Schmeck; Universities; Kiel; Germany; Waterloo; Canada; degrees; Dipl; Inform.; Dr. rer; nat.; Dr. habil; Kiel; Professor; Applied Informatics; Karlsruhe Institute; Technology; KIT; author; publications; algorithms; architectures; methods; optimisation; algorithms; architectures; self-organising; systems; program; conference chair; workshops; conferences; RAW; ARCS; IFIP BICC; ATC; ICAC; member; Organic Computing Initiative; coordinator; priority research program SPP; Organic Computing; Karlsruhe; Scientific Spokesperson; KIT-Focus COMMputation; challenges; combination; communication; computation; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e4ec001588 2 3----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 toronto:1 intellig:2 visit:1 scientist:1 electr:1 beng:1 prior:1 center:2 almaden:1 becom:1 inc:1 univers:3 clara:1 texa:2 cambridg:3 hewlett:1 affili:1 infocomm:1 california:1 jose:1 eec:1 meng:1 mose:1 schlumberg:2 degre:2 ucla:1 san:1 princeton:1 program:1 palo:1 luci:1 professor:2 comput:2 corpor:2 artifici:2 austin:2 singapor:1 henri:1 engin:1 lab:1 terzopoulo:1 endow:1 dauphin:1 santa:1 massachusett:2 leader:1 york:1 graduat:1 serv:1 nec:1 subsequ:1 institut:4 scienc:4 alto:1 honour:1 held:1 mr:1 mathemat:2 pari:1 receiv:1 mit:2 join:1 research:6 technolog:1 professorship:1 academ:1 courant:1 laboratori:2 mcgill:1 intel:1	||	Mr. Terzopoulos received the Ph.D. degree (1984) in EECS (Artificial Intelligence) from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and the M.Eng. and Honours B.Eng. degrees in Electrical Engineering from McGill University. After graduation, he was a research scientist at the MIT Artificial Intelligence Lab, Cambridge, Massachusetts. Prior to becoming an academic at Toronto in 1989, he was affiliated with Schlumberger, Inc., serving as a Program Leader at corporate research centers in Palo Alto, California, and Austin, Texas. He has been a visiting professor at IBM's Almaden Research Center in San Jose, at Intel Corporation in Santa Clara, at Digital's (subsequently Compaq's and Hewlett-Packard's) Cambridge Research Laboratory in Cambridge, at the NEC Research Institute in Princeton, at the Schlumberger Laboratory for Computer Science in Austin, Texas, at the Institute for Infocomm Research in Singapore, and at the University of Paris-Dauphine. He joined UCLA in 2005 from New York University, where he had been Professor of Computer Science and Mathematics at NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences since 2000 and held the Lucy and Henry Moses Endowed Professorship in Science.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Honours B. 4f8e5b6ae80eb0e4ec001588 2 5----Award----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:2 understand:1 toronto:1 pioneer:2 sae:1 intellig:1 award:8 foundat:1 doctor:1 contribut:1 creativ:1 student:2 sustain:1 univers:1 thesi:1 educ:1 academi:2 motion:2 vasilescu:1 recipi:2 dynam:1 aaai:1 work:9 dissert:1 contour:1 inaugur:1 art:2 signific:1 recognit:1 competit:1 imag:4 cite:1 digit:2 ieee:2 pictur:2 marr:1 simul:1 advanc:1 prize:1 canadian:1 comput:3 alex:1 magazin:1 citat:4 realiti:1 media:2 review:1 medic:3 autonom:1 artifici:2 virtual:3 model:5 anim:3 graphic:1 activ:1 applic:1 six:1 terzopoulo:1 nicograph:1 cloth:1 associ:2 societi:1 name:1 xiaoyuan:1 realist:1 deform:3 won:1 analysi:2 innov:1 scienc:2 top:1 outstand:1 technic:1 includ:1 acm:1 mr:1 vision:2 excel:1 ar:1 electronica:1 technolog:1 young:1 research:3 achiev:1 human:3 process:1 snake:1 informat:1 tu:1 pattern:1 facial:1 base:1 intern:3 premier:1	||	Mr. Terzopoulos is the recipient of a 2005 Academy Award for Technical Achievement from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for his pioneering work on realistic cloth simulation for motion pictures. In 2007, he was the inaugural recipient of the Computer Vision Significant Researcher Award from the IEEE "For his pioneering and sustained research on Deformable Models and their applications." His other citations include an award from the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) in 1987 for his work on deformable models in vision, a Marr Prize citation from the IEEE in 1987 for his work on active contours (snakes), an award from NICOGRAPH in 1996 for his work on human facial modeling and animation, two awards from Computers & Graphics in 2002 for his work on dynamic virtual humans and deformable models in medical image analysis, two citations from the International Medical Informatics Association in 1999 and 2003 for his work on model-based medical image analysis, a citation from SAE International in 2006 for his work on autonomous virtual humans, awards from the International Digital Media Foundation in 1994 and from Ars Electronica (the premier competition for creative work with digital media) in 1995 for his work on artificial animals for computer animation and virtual reality, and six University of Toronto Arts and Science Excellence Awards. In 1998 the Canadian Image Processing and Pattern Recognition Society cited him for his "outstanding contributions to research and education in image understanding." The Ph.D. thesis of his student Xiaoyuan Tu won the 1996 ACM Doctoral Dissertation Award and in 2003 his Ph.D. student Alex Vasilescu was named a TR100 Top Young Innovator by	##false@@false$$	Technology Review	##true@@false$$	magazine.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences; Advancement of Artificial Intelligence; Computers & Graphics; International Medical Informatics Association; SAE International; International Digital Media Foundation; Ars Electronica; University of Toronto Arts and Science Excellence Awards; Canadian Image Processing and Pattern Recognition Society; Top Young Innovator by Technology Review; 	PERSON: Mr. Terzopoulos; Xiaoyuan Tu; Alex Vasilescu; 	DATE: 2005; 2007; 1987; 1987; 1996; 2002; 1999; 2003; 2006; 1994; 1995; 1998; 1996; 2003; 	LOCATION: NICOGRAPH; 	NOUN: Mr. Terzopoulos; Academy Award; Technical Achievement; Academy; Motion Picture Arts; Sciences; work; cloth simulation; motion pictures; Computer Vision; Researcher Award; IEEE; research; Deformable Models; applications; citations; award; Association; Advancement; Artificial Intelligence; AAAI; work; models; vision; Marr Prize citation; IEEE; work; contours; snakes; award; NICOGRAPH; work; modeling; animation; awards; Computers; Graphics; work; humans; models; image analysis; citations; International Medical Informatics Association; work; image analysis; citation; SAE International; work; humans; awards; International Digital Media Foundation; Ars Electronica; premier competition; work; media; work; animals; computer animation; reality; University; Toronto Arts; Science Excellence Awards; Image Processing; Pattern Recognition Society; contributions; research; education; image understanding; Ph.D. thesis; student Xiaoyuan Tu; ACM Doctoral Dissertation Award; Ph.D. student Alex Vasilescu; TR100; Young Innovator; Technology Review magazine; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b50e80eb0e495ec1488 2 10----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	interior:1 phd:1 advisori:1 grant:1 siam:1 etc:1 cours:1 award:1 perform:1 approxim:1 electr:1 symposium:1 industri:2 prior:1 stanford:2 semidefinit:1 yinyu:1 univers:2 oper:4 varieti:1 year:1 fourteen:1 affili:1 recipi:1 work:1 courtesi:1 iowa:1 workshop:1 numer:1 select:1 tippi:1 hold:1 director:1 board:1 conic:1 nation:1 dimac:1 cite:1 co:1 system:2 editori:1 editor:1 princeton:1 program:5 professor:2 comput:2 distinguish:1 committe:1 discret:1 depart:1 decis:1 henri:1 wwwisihighlycitedcom:1 engin:6 applic:1 network:1 algorithm:1 graph:1 area:1 extens:1 written:1 econom:1 current:1 serv:2 institut:1 consult:1 scienc:4 member:1 fellowship:1 linear:1 ye:4 optim:5 manag:4 mathemat:3 speaker:2 ms:1 come:1 mit:1 semi:1 game:1 highli:1 markov:1 teach:1 research:7 section:1 point:1 school:1 organ:1 offic:1 intern:3 plenari:1 theori:1 method:1 local:1 integ:1	||	Yinyu Ye is Professor of Management Science and Engineering and, by courtesy, Electrical Engineering and the Director of the MS&E Industrial Affiliates Program at Stanford's School of Engineering. He holds a Ph.D. in Engineering Economic Systems and Operations Research from Stanford University. Prior to coming to Stanford in 2002, Ye served for fourteen years in the Management Science Department of the University of Iowa as the Henry Tippie Research Professor. He has been or was on the editorial board of Management Science, Operations Research, Mathematics of Operations Research, SIAM J Optimization; and the area editor of Optimization & Engineering. He was the recipient numerous international and national awards, fellowships and research grants, a semi-plenary speaker and member of the International Advisory Committee of the International Symposium on Mathematical Programming, the Section Officer (Linear Programming) of the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences, the co-organizer of the 1999 DIMACS Princeton workshop on discrete optimization, and the Distinguished Speaker in High Performance Computation for Engineered Systems of MIT. He was also selected as a highly cited mathematical researcher on	##false@@false$$	www.ISIhighlycited.com	##false@@true$$	. Ye teaches courses on Optimization, Network and Integer Programming, Semidefinite Programming, etc. He has written extensively on Interior-Point Methods, Approximation Algorithms, Conic Optimization, and their applications. Ye is currently working on Markov Decisions, Computational Game Theory and Graph Localization. He has served as a consultant to a variety of industries.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Professor of Management Science and Engineering; Electrical Engineering; Stanford 's School of Engineering; Engineering Economic Systems and Operations Research; Stanford University; Stanford; Management Science Department of the University of Iowa; Henry Tippie Research Professor; Management Science; Operations Research; Mathematics of Operations Research; International Advisory Committee of the International Symposium on Mathematical Programming; Institute for Operations Research; Management Sciences; Princeton; MIT; Network and Integer Programming; Conic Optimization; 	PERSON: Markov; 	DATE: 2002; 1999; 	NOUN: Yinyu Ye; Professor; Management Science; Engineering; courtesy; Engineering; Director; MS&E Industrial Affiliates Program; Stanford; School; Engineering; Ph.D.; Engineering Economic Systems; Operations Research; Stanford University; Stanford; Ye; years; Management Science Department; University; Iowa; Henry Tippie Research Professor; editorial board; Management Science; Operations Research; Mathematics; Operations Research; SIAM J Optimization; area editor; Optimization; Engineering; awards; fellowships; research grants; speaker; member; International Advisory Committee; International Symposium; Mathematical Programming; Section Officer; Linear Programming; Institute; Operations Research; Management Sciences; co-organizer; DIMACS Princeton workshop; optimization; Distinguished Speaker; High Performance Computation; Engineered Systems; MIT; researcher; www.ISIhighlycited.com; Ye; courses; Optimization; Network; Integer Programming; Semidefinite Programming; Interior-Point Methods; Approximation Algorithms; Conic Optimization; applications; Ye; Markov Decisions; Computational Game Theory; Graph Localization; consultant; variety; industries; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e468011588 3 31----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	primit:1 model:1 can:1 simpl:1 reason:1 obsolet:1 set:1 pseudo:2 knowledg:1 languag:4 pluscal:3 object:2 automat:1 algorithm:4 graph:1 altern:1 byte:1 best:1 usual:1 assum:1 check:1 mathemat:1 describ:2 code:2 translat:1 provid:1 checker:1 differ:1 formal:1 specif:1 term:1 program:4 exampl:1 instead:1 base:1 tlc:1 tla:3 make:1 integ:1	||	Algorithms are different from programs and should not be described with programming languages. For example, algorithms are usually best described in terms of mathematical objects like sets and graphs instead of the primitive objects like bytes and integers provided by programming languages. Until now, the only simple alternative to programming languages has been pseudo-code. PlusCal is an algorithm language based on TLA+. A PlusCal algorithm is automatically translated to a TLA+ specification that can be checked with the TLC model checker or reasoned about formally. (No knowledge of TLA+ is assumed.) PlusCal makes pseudo-code obsolete.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: PlusCal; TLA; TLA; TLC; TLA; 	NOUN: Algorithms; programs; programming languages; example; algorithms; terms; objects; sets; graphs; objects; bytes; integers; languages; alternative; programming languages; PlusCal; algorithm language; TLA; algorithm; TLA; specification; TLC model checker; knowledge; TLA; PlusCal; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

You have [a] standard test data set. It would be there, say 1,000 images, 100 of a car, 100 of a chair 100 of another object and so on, and you have the computer ask what is this image, and you measure to see if it got correct. We are testing, yes, but the problem is that if you just take those photos and the computer doesn t do a good job, you don t know why.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Laughs; idea; computer algorithm; computer; ability; images; algorithm; test data; images; car; chair; object; computer; image; problem; photos; computer doesn t; job; t; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b81e80eb0e4fb081588 5 3----Research----#text.P.A.BODY.HTML.#document	appear:1 can:1 gener:1 particular:1 recent:1 tettelin:1 close:2 minim:2 time:1 graph:1 requir:1 order:1 dna:1 sequenc:4 shotgun:1 scienc:1 includ:1 guarante:1 microbi:1 genom:3 multiplex:2 learn:1 describ:1 pcr:2 effort:1 involv:1 problem:2 us:2 number:2 framework:1 sever:1 procedur:2 project:2 al:1 whole:2 closur:1 strategi:1 comput:1 method:3 certain:1 reduc:1 et:1 pneumonia:1 streptococcu:1 step:1 propos:2 miss:1 gap:4	||	Tettelin et. al. proposed a new method for closing the gaps in whole genome shotgun sequencing projects. The method uses a multiplex PCR strategy in order to minimize the time and effort required to sequence the DNA in the missing gaps. This procedure has been used in a number of microbial sequencing projects including Streptococcus pneumoniae genome sequencing that recently appeared in Science. We describe a computational framework for gap closing. Our problem can be reduced to certain graph learning problems. We propose several methods that guarantee to minimize the number of steps involved in multiplex PCR procedures in general and whole genome gap closure in particular.	##false@@true$$		||	NOUN: Tettelin et; method; gaps; genome shotgun sequencing projects; method; PCR strategy; order; time; effort; sequence; DNA; gaps; procedure; number; sequencing projects; Streptococcus; genome sequencing; Science; framework; gap closing; problem; graph learning problems; methods; number; steps; PCR procedures; genome gap closure; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e47b011588 4 2----Award----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	gener:1 pioneer:1 hebrew:1 servic:1 substanti:1 award:2 rosenschein:3 foundat:1 confer:1 contribut:1 univers:1 among:1 social:1 autom:1 chief:1 recipi:1 work:1 sigart:1 select:1 agent:6 multiag:1 record:1 editor:1 jerusalem:1 system:3 co:2 multi:3 professor:4 comput:2 commun:1 committe:1 autonom:3 negoti:1 set:1 israel:1 journal:1 announc:1 pleas:1 area:1 jeffrei:1 presid:1 serv:1 honour:1 addit:1 acm:1 track:1 choic:1 us:1 game:1 research:1 techniqu:1 ifaama:1 chair:1 plan:1 mechan:1 intern:1 theori:1 design:1 aama:1	||	The selection committee for the ACM/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award is pleased to announce that the recipient of the 2013 award is Professor Jeffrey S. Rosenschein (The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel). Professor Rosenschein is honoured for his pioneering work on the use of game theory in multi-agent systems. Among Professor Rosenschein's many contributions in this area are techniques for automated negotiation, computational social choice, multi-agent planning, and mechanism design in computational settings. In addition, Professor Rosenschein has a substantial track record of community service, having been general co-chair for the AAMAS conference in 2003, president of the International Foundation for Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (IFAAMAS), and serving as co-editor-in-chief for the journal "Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems".	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Autonomous Agents Research Award; Hebrew University of Jerusalem; International Foundation for Autonomous Agents; 	PERSON: Jeffrey S. Rosenschein; Rosenschein; Rosenschein; Rosenschein; 	DATE: 2013; 2003; 	LOCATION: Israel; 	NOUN: selection committee; ACM\/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award; award; Professor Jeffrey S. Rosenschein; Hebrew University; Jerusalem; Israel; Professor Rosenschein; work; use; game theory; systems; Professor Rosenschein; contributions; area; techniques; negotiation; choice; planning; mechanism design; settings; addition; Professor Rosenschein; track record; community service; co-chair; AAMAS conference; president; International Foundation; Autonomous Agents; Multiagent Systems; IFAAMAS; co-editor-in-chief; journal; Autonomous Agents; Multi-Agent Systems; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

4f8e5b6ae80eb0e47b011588 5 2----Award----#text.P.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	gener:1 pioneer:1 hebrew:1 servic:1 substanti:1 award:2 rosenschein:3 foundat:1 confer:1 contribut:1 univers:1 among:1 social:1 autom:1 chief:1 recipi:1 work:1 sigart:1 select:1 agent:6 multiag:1 record:1 editor:1 jerusalem:1 system:3 co:2 multi:3 professor:4 comput:2 commun:1 committe:1 autonom:3 negoti:1 set:1 israel:1 journal:1 announc:1 pleas:1 area:1 jeffrei:1 presid:1 serv:1 honour:1 addit:1 acm:1 track:1 choic:1 us:1 game:1 research:1 techniqu:1 ifaama:1 chair:1 plan:1 mechan:1 intern:1 theori:1 design:1 aama:1	||	The selection committee for the ACM/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award is pleased to announce that the recipient of the 2013 award is Professor Jeffrey S. Rosenschein (The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel). Professor Rosenschein is honoured for his pioneering work on the use of game theory in multi-agent systems. Among Professor Rosenschein's many contributions in this area are techniques for automated negotiation, computational social choice, multi-agent planning, and mechanism design in computational settings. In addition, Professor Rosenschein has a substantial track record of community service, having been general co-chair for the AAMAS conference in 2003, president of the International Foundation for Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (IFAAMAS), and serving as co-editor-in-chief for the journal "Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems".	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Autonomous Agents Research Award; Hebrew University of Jerusalem; International Foundation for Autonomous Agents; 	PERSON: Jeffrey S. Rosenschein; Rosenschein; Rosenschein; Rosenschein; 	DATE: 2013; 2003; 	LOCATION: Israel; 	NOUN: selection committee; ACM\/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award; award; Professor Jeffrey S. Rosenschein; Hebrew University; Jerusalem; Israel; Professor Rosenschein; work; use; game theory; systems; Professor Rosenschein; contributions; area; techniques; negotiation; choice; planning; mechanism design; settings; addition; Professor Rosenschein; track record; community service; co-chair; AAMAS conference; president; International Foundation; Autonomous Agents; Multiagent Systems; IFAAMAS; co-editor-in-chief; journal; Autonomous Agents; Multi-Agent Systems; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
4f8e5b6ae80eb0e47b011588 5 3----Award----#text.A.P.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	sycara:1 award:5 confer:1 milind:1 jen:1 import:1 fund:1 offici:1 gratch:1 recogn:1 recipi:1 work:1 sigart:3 creat:1 whose:1 jonathan:1 aaawardhtm:1 halpern:1 agent:4 inform:1 present:1 staci:1 mosh:1 tennenholtz:1 http:1 proce:1 tamb:1 nichola:1 katia:1 autonom:4 krau:1 makoto:1 area:1 joe:1 endow:1 shoham:1 tuoma:1 sarit:1 current:1 marsella:1 veloso:1 yokoo:1 annual:1 acm:4 wooldridg:1 excel:1 research:4 field:1 sigartacmorg:1 sandholm:1 michael:1 influenc:1 manuela:1 yoav:1 intend:1 previou:1	||	The ACM/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award is presented annually for research excellence in the area of autonomous agents. It is intended to recognize researchers whose current work is an important influence on the field. The award is an official ACM award, funded by an endowment created by ACM SIGART from the proceeds of Autonomous Agents conferences. Previous recipients of the ACM/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award were: Moshe Tennenholtz (2012), Joe Halpern (2011), Jonathan Gratch and Stacy Marsella (2010), Manuela Veloso (2009), Yoav Shoham (2008), Sarit Kraus (2007), Michael Wooldridge (2006), Milind Tambe (2005), Makoto Yokoo (2004), Nicholas R. Jennings (2003), Katia Sycara (2002), and Tuomas Sandholm (2001). For more information on the award, see:	##false@@false$$	http://sigart.acm.org/aaaward.htm	##false@@true$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Autonomous Agents Research Award; Autonomous Agents Research Award; 	PERSON: Joe Halpern; Jonathan Gratch; Stacy Marsella; Manuela Veloso; Yoav Shoham; Sarit Kraus; Michael Wooldridge; Milind Tambe; Makoto Yokoo; Nicholas R. Jennings; Katia Sycara; 	DATE: 2012; 2011; 2010; 2009; 2008; 2007; 2006; 2005; 2004; 2003; 2002; 2001; 	NOUN: ACM\/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award; research excellence; area; agents; researchers; work; influence; field; award; ACM award; endowment; ACM SIGART; proceeds; Autonomous Agents conferences; recipients; ACM\/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award; Moshe Tennenholtz; Joe Halpern; Jonathan Gratch; Stacy Marsella; Manuela Veloso; Yoav Shoham; Sarit Kraus; Michael Wooldridge; Milind Tambe; Makoto Yokoo; Nicholas R. 406605-2 14 2----Research----#text.A.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	histor:1 tool:1 time:1 student:2 page:1 respond:1 event:1 propag:1 surviv:1 examin:1 work:1 worm:1 support:2 continu:1 mose:1 project:3 system:4 scenario:1 simul:2 professor:1 commun:1 comput:1 demonstr:1 properti:1 hybrid:1 critic:1 home:1 scale:3 discret:1 model:4 infrastructur:2 behavior:2 line:1 cyber:1 run:1 recent:1 issu:1 network:5 applic:1 real:1 prof:1 scada:1 methodolog:1 exercis:1 develop:4 look:1 us:3 game:1 evalu:2 rout:1 techniqu:1 eg:1 secur:3 organ:1 larg:3 mechan:1 nicol:2 context:1 exampl:1 interact:1 attack:1 studi:2 design:1	||	Professor Nicol and his students have been studying the security properties of large-scale systems through Project MOSES. The project is examining large-scale system behavior and developing simulation and modeling methodology that supports demonstration and evaluation of that behavior. Historically Prof. Nicol and his students have studied computer and communication networks. However, many of the techniques and tools they've developed have applications in other contexts. They use continuous, discrete-event, and hybrid models. Their recent work looks at issues in network security. For example, one project is modeling worm propagation and its interaction with the Internet's routing infrastructure. Another is developing and modeling security mechanisms in a p2p network designed to support the survivability of networks running critical infrastructure (e.g., SCADA systems). Still another is developing an on-line real-time network simulator of large-scale systems for use in exercise and scenario games used to evaluate how organizations respond to cyber-attacks.	##false@@false$$	Home Page	##false@@true$$		||	PERSON: Nicol; MOSES; Nicol; 	NOUN: Professor Nicol; students; security properties; systems; Project MOSES; project; system behavior; simulation; modeling methodology; demonstration; evaluation; behavior; Historically Prof. Nicol; students; computer; communication networks; techniques; tools; applications; contexts; hybrid models; work; issues; network security; example; project; modeling worm propagation; interaction; Internet; infrastructure; modeling security mechanisms; p2p network; survivability; networks; infrastructure; SCADA systems; network simulator; systems; use; exercise; scenario games; organizations; cyber-attacks; Home Page; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

His widely cited work, "Actors: A Model of Concurrent Computing in Distributed Systems," (MIT Press, 1986) provided a basis for a number of research projects in concurrent programming. He has co-edited another book, "Research Directions in Concurrent Object Oriented Programming" (MIT Press, 1993).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Computer Science; MIT Press; MIT Press; 	PERSON: Dr. Gul Agha; 	DATE: 1986; 1993; 	NOUN: Dr. Gul Agha; Director; Open Systems Laboratory; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Professor; Department; Computer Science; work; Actors; Model; Computing; Systems; MIT Press; basis; number; research projects; programming; book; Research Directions; Object Oriented Programming; MIT Press; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$
456481-0 1 14----Research----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	result:1 idea:1 understand:1 concurr:2 maintain:1 distribut:1 proof:1 lead:1 natur:1 languag:1 perform:1 build:1 applic:1 clear:1 real:1 open:1 time:1 requir:1 semant:1 practic:1 develop:2 theoret:1 toler:1 softwar:1 support:1 composit:1 principl:1 fault:1 provid:2 research:3 goal:3 techniqu:1 system:3 specif:1 experi:1 program:2 professor:1 comput:1 theori:1 wai:1 construct:1 group:1	||	The goal of Professor Agha's research is to understand the nature of concurrent computation. Results of the research will lead to new ways for building and maintaining open distributed systems. Specifically, Agha's group is developing concurrent programming languages and systems which support applications with high-performance, fault-tolerance or real-time requirements. The group's research is both theoretical and practical. The goal of the theory is to provide a clear semantics for new programming constructs and software composition techniques. The goal of developing systems to experiment with the ideas and provide a proof of principle.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Agha; Agha; 	NOUN: goal; Professor Agha; research; nature; computation; Results; research; ways; building; systems; Agha; group; programming languages; systems; applications; requirements; group; research; goal; theory; semantics; programming constructs; software composition techniques; goal; systems; experiment; ideas; proof; principle; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

ITRA seeks competitive, collaborative proposals to initiate the MNA sub-pyramid. With the tremendous advancement and growing coverage of cellular and wireless access networks, decreasing costs and increasing capabilities of mobile phones, it is becoming clear that mobile phones are likely theinterface of choice for access to many services over the Internet.
