289132-0 0 14----Research----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	reconfigur:1 integr:2 singl:1 higher:1 cycl:1 lead:1 scalabl:1 reus:2 industri:1 kei:2 semiconductor:2 time:1 transistor:1 level:2 altern:1 given:1 chen:1 exponenti:1 power:1 year:2 deep:1 follow:1 platform:2 control:1 creat:1 billion:1 manufactur:3 team:1 cost:4 continu:1 size:1 nanotechnolog:1 system:1 submicron:1 grown:1 pursu:1 comput:2 due:1 novel:1 wall:1 meanwhil:1 compil:1 gap:1 solut:2 increas:3 scale:2 spectacular:1 complex:2 brick:1 lengthi:1 explor:1 engin:1 mainli:1 roadmap:2 cmo:1 space:1 silicon:2 issu:1 prof:1 implement:1 synthesi:2 develop:2 direct:1 abstract:1 chip:2 domin:1 includ:2 optim:1 physic:1 manag:1 us:1 problem:1 accord:1 research:2 technolog:3 inher:1 product:1 red:1 led:1 address:1 larg:1 evolv:1 closur:1 context:1 intern:1 circuit:1 alreadi:1 significantli:1 group:1 fpga:2 design:12	||	According to the International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors, the spectacular CMOS technology scaling will continue to evolve and dominate the semiconductor industry for another 10 years. This will lead to over 14 billion transistors integrated on a single chip by the year 2018. Such a scaling has already created a large design productivity gap due to inherent design complexities and deep submicron issues. Meanwhile, development cost, including both the design cost and manufacturing cost, of integrated circuits has grown significantly given the increasing size of the design team and the lengthy design cycles. Both problems, if not addressed, will be the red brick walls on the technology roadmap. Some key solutions for managing the exponential increase of the design complexity are the development of more scalable optimization engines, higher level of design abstraction, and design reuse. Some key solutions for controlling the increase in manufacturing cost are design for manufacturing, use of alternative silicon implementation platforms, and silicon reuse. In this context, the research group led by Prof. Chen will mainly pursue the following research directions: FPGA synthesis and physical design for timing and power closure, compilation and high-level synthesis, design space exploration for system-on-chip, reconfigurable computing, and the design of novel computing platforms, including FPGAs with nanotechnology.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors; CMOS; FPGA; 	PERSON: Chen; 	DATE: 2018; 	NOUN: International Technology Roadmap; Semiconductors; CMOS technology scaling; semiconductor industry; years; transistors; chip; year; scaling; design productivity gap; design complexities; submicron issues; development cost; design cost; manufacturing cost; circuits; size; design team; design cycles; problems; brick walls; technology roadmap; solutions; increase; design complexity; development; optimization engines; level; design abstraction; design reuse; solutions; increase; cost; design; manufacturing; use; silicon implementation platforms; silicon reuse; context; research group; Prof. Chen; research directions; FPGA synthesis; design; timing; power closure; compilation; synthesis; design space exploration; system-on-chip; computing; design; computing platforms; FPGAs; nanotechnology; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

352191-2 12 6----Bio----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	illinoi:1 phd:1 intellig:1 award:2 electr:1 foundat:1 urbana:1 beij:1 confer:2 tsinghua:1 univers:3 interest:1 autom:1 china:1 california:1 art:1 career:1 eec:2 higgin:1 nation:1 degre:4 machin:1 ieee:2 editor:1 appli:1 system:1 marr:1 european:1 transact:1 prize:2 bachelor:1 professor:1 comput:4 david:1 senior:1 depart:1 paper:2 engin:1 naval:1 champaign:1 associ:2 ma:3 best:2 analysi:1 scienc:2 member:2 includ:1 acm:1 vision:3 mathemat:2 receiv:3 research:2 young:1 master:2 longuet:1 pattern:1 offic:1 intern:1 investig:1 theori:1 yi:3 berkelei:1	||	Yi Ma is an associate professor at the Electrical & Computer Engineering Department of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. His research interests include computer vision and systems theory. Yi Ma received two Bachelors degree in Automation and Applied Mathematics from Tsinghua University (Beijing, China) in 1995, a Master of Science degree in EECS in 1997, a Master of Arts degree in Mathematics in 2000, and a PhD degree in EECS in 2000, all from the University of California at Berkeley. Yi Ma received the David Marr Best Paper Prize at the International Conference on Computer Vision 1999 and the Longuet-Higgins Best Paper Prize at the European Conference on Computer Vision 2004. He also received the CAREER Award from the National Science Foundation in 2004 and the Young Investigator Award from the Office of Naval Research in 2005. He is an associate editor of IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence. He is a senior member of IEEE and a member of ACM.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Electrical & Computer Engineering Department of the University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Tsinghua University; EECS; EECS; University of California; International Conference on Computer Vision; European Conference on Computer Vision; National Science Foundation; Office of Naval Research; Machine Intelligence; 	PERSON: Yi Ma; Yi Ma; Yi Ma; David Marr; 	DATE: 1995; 1997; 2000; 2000; 1999; 2004; 2004; 2005; 	LOCATION: Beijing; China; Berkeley; 	NOUN: Yi Ma; professor; Computer Engineering Department; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; research interests; computer vision; systems theory; Yi Ma; Bachelors degree; Automation; Applied Mathematics; Tsinghua University; Beijing; China; Master; Science degree; EECS; Master; Arts degree; Mathematics; PhD degree; EECS; University; California; Berkeley; Yi Ma; David Marr; Paper Prize; International Conference; Computer Vision; Longuet-Higgins; Paper Prize; Conference; Computer Vision; CAREER Award; National Science Foundation; Young Investigator Award; Office; Naval Research; editor; IEEE Transactions; Pattern Analysis; Machine Intelligence; member; IEEE; member; ACM; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

352191-2 3 6----Bio----#text.SPAN.P.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	illinoi:1 intellig:1 electr:1 faculti:1 urbana:1 beij:1 estim:1 univers:1 interest:1 proceed:1 affili:1 chief:1 coordin:1 topic:1 control:1 multipl:1 januari:1 board:1 machin:1 ieee:3 system:2 editor:2 visual:1 transact:1 program:2 tenur:1 professor:2 comput:5 magazin:1 view:1 hybrid:1 geometri:1 model:1 depart:2 engin:1 data:1 signal:1 issu:1 recent:1 microsoft:1 journal:1 champaign:1 area:1 associ:3 ma:1 asia:1 classif:1 serv:3 analysi:1 institut:1 scienc:2 member:1 includ:2 vision:3 manag:1 iccv:2 research:5 beckman:1 process:1 chair:2 dimension:1 pattern:1 intern:1 laboratori:1 base:1 guest:1 cluster:1 special:1 theori:1 nip:1 group:1 yi:1	||	Yi Ma	##false@@false$$	is an associate professor (with tenure) in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also an affiliated faculty of the Computer Science Department, and a research associate professor in the Coordinated Science Laboratory and the Beckman Institute. Since January 2009, he has served as a research manager for the Visual Computing Group at Microsoft Research Asia, Beijing. His research interests include computer vision and systems theory. Recent research topics include multiple-view geometry, vision-based control, clustering and classification of high-dimensional data, estimation of hybrid models and systems. He is an associate editor of the	##false@@false$$	IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence	##false@@false$$	since 2007 and the International Journal of Computer Vision since 2010. He has also served as the chief guest editor for special issues for the Proceedings of IEEE and the IEEE Signal Processing Magazine. He serves as Area Chair for NIPS 2011, Program Board Member for ICCV 2011, and Program Chair for ICCV 2013.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Computer Science Department; Coordinated Science Laboratory; Beckman Institute; Visual Computing Group; Microsoft Research Asia; Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence; International Journal of Computer Vision; IEEE Signal Processing Magazine; Program Board; 	PERSON: Yi Ma; 	DATE: 2009; 2007; 2010; 2011; 2011; 2013; 	LOCATION: Beijing; 	NOUN: Yi Ma; professor; tenure; Department; Computer Engineering; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; faculty; Computer Science Department; research; professor; Coordinated Science Laboratory; Beckman Institute; January; research manager; Visual Computing Group; Microsoft Research Asia; Beijing; research interests; computer vision; systems theory; research topics; geometry; control; clustering; classification; data; estimation; hybrid models; systems; editor; IEEE Transactions; Pattern Analysis; Machine Intelligence; International Journal; Computer Vision; chief guest editor; issues; Proceedings; IEEE; IEEE Signal Processing Magazine; Area Chair; NIPS; Program Board Member; ICCV; Program Chair; ICCV; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

He received the B.S. degrees in electrical engineering and applied mathematics (with honors) and the M.S. degree in applied mathematics from North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, in 2004 and 2005, respectively.He received the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from the University of Maryland, College Park, MD, in 2010. His research interests include biometrics, radar imaging, applied harmonic analysis and inverse problems. 352191-1 5 8----Bio----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 siam:1 foundat:1 urbana:1 beij:2 tsinghua:1 interest:1 autom:1 california:1 art:1 career:1 degre:4 system:1 editor:2 ieee:4 visual:1 european:1 transact:1 ase:1 prize:2 bachelor:1 professor:1 david:1 depart:1 engin:1 data:1 issu:1 associ:2 ma:3 best:3 publish:1 analysi:2 scienc:2 invit:1 member:2 sang:1 uk:1 receiv:3 research:4 young:1 master:2 process:1 chair:1 lee:1 pattern:1 offic:1 intern:1 guest:1 illinoi:1 intellig:1 award:3 electr:1 asian:1 confer:3 student:2 univers:3 proceed:1 chief:1 china:1 textbook:1 januari:1 eec:2 higgin:1 nation:1 appli:1 marr:1 machin:1 program:1 popular:1 australia:1 comput:6 magazin:1 senior:1 springer:1 paper:3 signal:1 microsoft:1 author:1 champaign:1 naval:1 asia:1 serv:2 acm:1 vision:6 mathemat:2 manag:1 iccv:1 sydnei:1 main:1 dimension:1 longuet:1 investig:1 theori:1 special:1 group:1 berkelei:1 yi:3	||	Yi MA	##false@@true$$	is an associate professor at the Electrical & Computer Engineering Department of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He is also the research manager of the Visual Computing group at Microsoft Research Asia in Beijing since January 2009. His main research interest is in computer vision, high-dimensional data analysis, and systems theory.He is the first author of the popular vision textbook	##false@@false$$	"An Invitation to 3-D Vision,"	##false@@true$$	published by Springer in 2003.Yi Ma received two Bachelors' degree in Automation and Applied Mathematics from Tsinghua University (Beijing, China) in 1995, a Master of Science degree in EECS in 1997, a Master of Arts degree in Mathematics in 2000, and a PhD degree in EECS in 2000, all from the University of California at Berkeley. Yi Ma received the David Marr Best Paper Prize at the International Conference on Computer Vision 1999, the Longuet-Higgins Best Paper Prize at the European Conference on Computer Vision 2004,and the Sang Uk Lee Best Student Paper Award with his students at the Asian Conference on Computer Vision in 2009.He also received the CAREER Award from the National Science Foundation in 2004 and the Young Investigator Award from the Office of Naval Research in 2005. He is an associate editor of IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence and has served as the chief guest editor for special issues for the Proceedings of IEEE and the IEEE Signal Processing Magazine. He will also serve as Program Chair for ICCV 2013 in Sydney, Australia.He is a senior member of IEEE and a member of ACM, SIAM, and ASEE.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Yi MA; Electrical & Computer Engineering Department of the University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Visual Computing; Microsoft Research Asia; Tsinghua University; EECS; EECS; University of California; International Conference on Computer Vision; European Conference on Computer Vision; Sang Uk Lee Best Student; Asian Conference on Computer Vision; National Science Foundation; Office of Naval Research; Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence; IEEE Signal Processing Magazine; ASEE; 	PERSON: Springer; Yi Ma; Yi Ma; David Marr; 	DATE: 2009; 2003; 1995; 1997; 2000; 2000; 1999; 2004; 2009; 2004; 2005; 2013; 	LOCATION: Beijing; Beijing; China; Berkeley; Sydney; Australia; SIAM; 	NOUN: Yi MA; professor; Computer Engineering Department; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; research manager; Visual Computing group; Microsoft Research Asia; Beijing; January; research interest; computer vision; data analysis; systems theory; author; vision textbook; Invitation; Vision; Springer; Yi Ma; Bachelors; degree; Automation; Applied Mathematics; Tsinghua University; Beijing; China; Master; Science degree; EECS; Master; Arts degree; Mathematics; PhD degree; EECS; University; California; Berkeley; Yi Ma; David Marr; Paper Prize; International Conference; Computer Vision; Longuet-Higgins; Paper Prize; Conference; Computer Vision; Sang Uk Lee; Student Paper Award; students; Conference; Computer Vision; CAREER Award; National Science Foundation; Young Investigator Award; Office; Naval Research; editor; IEEE Transactions; Pattern Analysis; Machine Intelligence; chief guest editor; issues; Proceedings; IEEE; IEEE Signal Processing Magazine; Program Chair; ICCV; Sydney; Australia; member; IEEE; member; ACM; SIAM; ASEE; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

352191-3 10 2----Bio----#text.BODY.HTML.#document	phd:1 illinoi:1 gener:1 infer:1 intellig:1 ijcv:1 visit:2 electr:2 spain:1 urbana:1 beij:3 tsinghua:1 tpami:1 univers:3 proceed:1 autom:1 educ:1 chief:1 china:5 sichuan:1 coordin:1 control:1 januari:2 california:1 hold:2 eec:3 format:1 imag:1 inform:1 degre:4 machin:1 ieee:3 editor:3 appli:1 visual:1 transact:1 program:1 australia:1 tenur:1 bachelor:1 professor:3 comput:4 magazin:1 adjunct:1 senior:1 born:1 univeristi:1 depart:2 decis:1 engin:2 signal:1 issu:1 spring:1 microsoft:2 journal:3 chile:1 champaign:1 area:1 associ:4 ma:1 asia:2 serv:5 analysi:1 institut:1 scienc:3 vision:1 provinc:1 manag:1 mathemat:2 receiv:2 iccv:3 technolog:1 research:5 master:2 professorship:2 beckman:1 process:2 chair:3 ima:1 pattern:1 experi:1 fall:1 intern:1 laboratori:1 guest:2 special:1 nip:1 uc:1 group:3 yi:1 berkelei:2	||	Education and Experience:	##true@@false$$	Yi Ma was born in	##false@@false$$	Sichuan Province	##true@@true$$	, China. He received Bachelors degree in Automation and Applied Mathematics from	##false@@false$$	Tsinghua University	##true@@true$$	, Beijing, China, in 1995. He received an Master degree in Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences (EECS) in 1997, a second Master degree in Mathematics in 2000, and the Ph.D. degree in EECS in 2000, all from the	##false@@false$$	University of California at Berkeley	##true@@true$$	. From 2000 to 2011, he served as a tenured associated professor of the	##false@@false$$	Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering	##true@@true$$	University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign	##true@@true$$	, where he now holds an Adjunct Professorship. He also serves as a research associate professor both in the Decision & Control Group of the	##false@@false$$	Coordinated Science Laboratory	##true@@true$$	and in the Image Formation & Processing Group of the	##false@@false$$	Beckman Institute	##true@@true$$	. He was a visiting senior researcher at the Microsoft Research Asia, Beijing, China in fall 2006 and a visiting professor at EECS Department of UC Berkeley in spring 2007. Since January 2009, he has served as research manager for the	##false@@false$$	Visual Computing Group	##true@@true$$	at Microsoft Research Asia, Beijing, China. From January 2012, he also holds a Guest Professorship at the Univeristy of Science and Technology of China. He was an associate editor of the	##false@@false$$	IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence (TPAMI)	##true@@true$$	from 2007 to 2011. He is now the associate editor for the	##false@@false$$	International Journal of Computer Vision (IJCV)	##true@@true$$	and the journal on	##false@@false$$	Information and Inference (a Journal of the IMA)	##true@@true$$	. He has also served as the chief guest editor for special issues for the Proceedings of IEEE and the IEEE Signal Processing Magazine. He serves as Area Chair for NIPS 2011 and ICCV 2011 (Spain), Program Chair for ICCV 2013 (Australia), and General Chair for ICCV 2015 (Chile).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Tsinghua University; Computer Sciences; 352191-3 10 3----Research----#text.BODY.HTML.#document	face:1 springer:2 hundr:1 gener:1 structur:1 broad:1 segment:1 data:2 natur:1 approxim:1 recent:1 applic:1 expect:1 author:1 rank:1 area:1 spars:1 interest:2 reconstruct:1 current:1 classif:1 analysi:1 publish:3 invit:1 peer:1 topic:1 work:2 textbook:1 includ:2 vision:2 align:1 rectifi:1 recognit:1 imag:3 research:3 represent:1 system:1 dimension:2 compon:1 articl:1 book:1 comput:1 cluster:1 theori:1 low:1 review:1 princip:1 found:1	||	Research Interest:	##true@@false$$	His research interests include computer vision and systems theory. Recent research topics include	##false@@false$$	sparse representation	##true@@true$$	and	##false@@false$$	low-rank approximation	##true@@true$$	for high-dimensional data,	##false@@false$$	clustering and classification of high-dimensional data	##true@@true$$	, and	##false@@false$$	reconstruction 3D structures from images	##true@@true$$	. His work has found broad applications in areas such as	##false@@false$$	segmentation of natural images	##true@@true$$	face recognition	##true@@true$$	, aligning and rectifying images. He has published more than a hundred peer-reviewed articles. He is the first author of the textbook	##false@@false$$	An Invitation to 3-D Vision,	##true@@true$$	published by Springer in 2003. He is currently working on a new book,	##false@@false$$	Generalized Principal Component Analysis,	##true@@true$$	expected to be published by Springer.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Springer; Springer; 	DATE: 2003; 	NOUN: Research Interest; research interests; computer vision; systems theory; research topics; representation; approximation; data; clustering; classification; data; reconstruction 3D structures; images; work; applications; areas; segmentation; images; recognition; images; articles; author; textbook; Invitation; Vision; Springer; book; Generalized Principal Component Analysis; Springer; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

He is also the   research manager of the Visual Computing group at Microsoft Research Asia in   Beijing since January 2009. His main research interest is in computer vision,   high-dimensional data analysis, and systems theory.He is the first   author of the popular vision textbook	##false@@false$$	"An   Invitation to 3-D Vision,"	##false@@true$$	published by Springer in 2003.Yi   Ma received two Bachelors degree in Automation and Applied Mathematics from Tsinghua   University (Beijing, China) in 1995, a Master of Science degree in EECS in   1997, a Master of Arts degree in Mathematics in 2000, and a PhD degree in   EECS in 2000, all from the University of California at Berkeley. Yi Ma   received the David Marr Best Paper Prize at the International Conference on   Computer Vision 1999, the Longuet-Higgins Best Paper Prize at the European   Conference on Computer Vision 2004,	##false@@false$$	and the Sang   Uk Lee Best Student Paper Award with his students at the Asian Conference on   Computer Vision in 2009.He also received the CAREER Award from the National   Science Foundation in 2004 and the Young Investigator Award from the Office   of Naval Research in 2005. He is an associate editor of IEEE Transactions on   Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence and has served as the chief guest   editor for special issues for the Proceedings of IEEE and the IEEE Signal   Processing Magazine. Iyer is Interim Vice Chancellor for Research at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where he is a George and Ann Fisher Distinguished Professor of Engineering. He holds appointments in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and the Department of Computer Science and he is Director of the Center for Reliable and High-Performance Computing at the Coordinated Science Laboratory (CSL) and Chief Scientist at the Information Trust Institute (ITI). His research interests are in the area of dependable and secure systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Department of Computer Science; Center for Reliable; Coordinated Science Laboratory; CSL; Information Trust Institute; ITI; 	PERSON: Ravishankar K. 703753-1 11 2----Bio----#text.SPAN.DD.DL.LI.OL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	aiaa:1 georg:1 illinoi:1 govern:1 pioneer:1 award:4 astronaut:1 perform:1 scientist:2 electr:2 foundat:1 industri:1 urbana:1 center:1 chancellor:1 contribut:2 toward:1 univers:1 interest:1 internation:1 year:1 ann:1 focus:1 fisher:1 chief:1 work:1 coordin:1 respons:1 hold:1 director:1 nation:1 interim:1 record:1 inform:2 ieee:1 system:6 machineri:1 strong:1 advanc:2 reliabl:2 iyer:3 professor:1 comput:7 distinguish:2 emanuel:1 fellow:2 medal:1 senior:1 iti:1 valid:2 aerospac:1 broad:1 depart:2 vice:1 appoint:1 engin:3 applic:1 network:1 champaign:1 area:1 associ:3 american:2 electron:1 institut:3 toler:1 scienc:3 major:2 dr:2 addit:1 includ:1 vendor:1 trust:1 depend:2 fundament:2 excel:1 receiv:1 evalu:2 fault:1 teach:1 outreach:1 research:5 sever:2 techniqu:1 secur:2 aeronaut:1 laboratori:1 csl:1 measur:1 method:1 humboldt:1 ravishankar:1 design:4 pior:1	||	Ravishankar K. Iyer is Interim Vice Chancellor for Research at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where he is a George and Ann Fisher Distinguished Professor of Engineering. He holds appointments in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and the Department of Computer Science and he is Director of the Center for Reliable and High-Performance Computing at the Coordinated Science Laboratory (CSL) and Chief Scientist at the Information Trust Institute (ITI). His research interests are in the area of dependable and secure systems.    Dr. Iyer has been responsible for major advances in the design and validation of computing systems. His research focuses on methods and techniques for designing secure and fault tolerant networked systems and applications. In addition to his strong research record, he also has a broad outreach to industry and government, both nationally and internationally, having worked with several major vendors over the years.  Dr. Iyer is a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Association for Computing Machinery and American Association for the Advancement of Science; and an Associate Fellow of the American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics. He has received several awards including the Humboldt Foundation Senior Distinguished Scientist Award for excellence in research and teaching, the AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal for fundamental and pioneering contributions towards the design, evaluation, and validation of dependable aerospace computing systems, and the IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award for fundamental contributions to measurement, evaluation, and design of reliable computing systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Department of Computer Science; Center for Reliable; Coordinated Science Laboratory; CSL; Information Trust Institute; ITI; Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers , Association for Computing Machinery and American Association; Advancement of Science; American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics; Humboldt Foundation; AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal; 	PERSON: Ravishankar K. 703753-1 3 93----Bio----#text.SPAN.DD.DL.LI.OL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	aiaa:1 georg:1 illinoi:1 govern:1 pioneer:1 award:4 astronaut:1 perform:1 scientist:2 electr:2 foundat:1 industri:1 urbana:1 center:1 chancellor:1 contribut:2 toward:1 univers:1 interest:1 internation:1 year:1 ann:1 focus:1 fisher:1 chief:1 work:1 coordin:1 respons:1 hold:1 director:1 nation:1 interim:1 record:1 inform:2 ieee:1 system:6 machineri:1 strong:1 advanc:2 reliabl:2 iyer:3 professor:1 comput:7 distinguish:2 emanuel:1 fellow:2 medal:1 senior:1 iti:1 valid:2 aerospac:1 broad:1 depart:2 vice:1 appoint:1 engin:3 applic:1 network:1 champaign:1 area:1 associ:3 american:2 electron:1 institut:3 toler:1 scienc:3 major:2 dr:2 addit:1 includ:1 vendor:1 trust:1 depend:2 fundament:2 excel:1 receiv:1 evalu:2 fault:1 teach:1 outreach:1 research:5 sever:2 techniqu:1 secur:2 aeronaut:1 laboratori:1 csl:1 measur:1 method:1 humboldt:1 ravishankar:1 design:4 pior:1	||	Ravishankar K. Iyer is Interim Vice Chancellor for Research at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where he is a George and Ann Fisher Distinguished Professor of Engineering. He holds appointments in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and the Department of Computer Science and he is Director of the Center for Reliable and High-Performance Computing at the Coordinated Science Laboratory (CSL) and Chief Scientist at the Information Trust Institute (ITI). His research interests are in the area of dependable and secure systems.    Dr. Iyer has been responsible for major advances in the design and validation of computing systems. His research focuses on methods and techniques for designing secure and fault tolerant networked systems and applications. In addition to his strong research record, he also has a broad outreach to industry and government, both nationally and internationally, having worked with several major vendors over the years.  Dr. Iyer is a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Association for Computing Machinery and American Association for the Advancement of Science; and an Associate Fellow of the American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics. He has received several awards including the Humboldt Foundation Senior Distinguished Scientist Award for excellence in research and teaching, the AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal for fundamental and pioneering contributions towards the design, evaluation, and validation of dependable aerospace computing systems, and the IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award for fundamental contributions to measurement, evaluation, and design of reliable computing systems.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; Department of Computer Science; Center for Reliable; Coordinated Science Laboratory; CSL; Information Trust Institute; ITI; Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers , Association for Computing Machinery and American Association; Advancement of Science; American Institute for Aeronautics and Astronautics; Humboldt Foundation; AIAA Information Systems Award and Medal; 	PERSON: Ravishankar K. Iyer; Ann Fisher; Dr. Iyer; Dr. Iyer; Emanuel R. Piore; 	NOUN: Ravishankar K. 703753-1 10 2----Bio----#text.A.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	reconfigur:1 malici:1 injector:2 vulner:1 time:1 overhead:1 given:1 page:1 pipelin:1 interest:1 processor:1 support:2 runtim:1 avail:2 attract:1 provid:4 goal:1 project:5 system:4 simul:2 iyer:2 professor:2 low:1 home:1 accident:1 microprocessor:1 common:2 engin:4 block:1 build:1 applic:3 guard:1 embodi:1 toler:1 failur:1 librari:2 superscalar:1 fault:9 framework:4 techniqu:3 compon:2 mechan:2 base:1 hardwar:3 dictionari:2 attack:1 part:1 design:3 illinoi:1 detail:1 integr:1 mask:1 lead:2 possibl:1 perform:1 type:1 rse:1 function:1 level:2 varieti:1 modul:2 umbrella:1 environ:1 descript:2 embed:2 input:1 reliabl:5 contain:1 execut:1 output:1 characterist:2 call:1 model:1 can:1 set:1 area:1 implement:1 develop:4 coverag:1 detect:2 parallel:1 includ:1 error:2 check:1 uniform:1 depend:5 inject:1 produc:1 analyz:1 sever:1 secur:7 effect:1 take:1 awar:3 circuit:1 manner:1 core:2 devic:1 vhdl:1 recoveri:1	||	Professor Iyer is interested in developing and analyzing techniques for developing secure and reliable systems. He leads several projects in this area. One project is the Reconfigurable Reliability and Security Engine. A common processor-level framework that can provide application-aware reliability and security is attractive and timely. The Reliability and Security Engine project at Illinois is developing a common framework to provide a variety of application-aware techniques for error-detection, masking of security vulnerabilities, and recovery under one umbrella in a uniform, low-overhead manner. Hardware-implemented error-detection and security mechanisms are embedded as modules in the hardware-level framework, called the Reliability and Security Engine (RSE), which has been designed as an integral part of a superscalar microprocessor. The embedded hardware modules execute in parallel with the core pipeline. The goal of the project is to provide application-aware runtime checking techniques to guard against both accidental failures and malicious attacks. Another project Professor Iyer leads is DEPEND, which is developing a framework for designing dependable systems. DEPEND is a simulation-based environment that supports the design of systems for fault tolerance and high availability. It takes as inputs both VHDL and C++ system description and produces as output dependability characteristics including fault coverage, availability, and performance. At the core of DEPEND are simulation engines supported by a fault injector, a set of fault dictionaries, and component libraries. The fault injector provides mechanisms to inject faults. The component libraries contain model-building blocks with detailed functional descriptions and characteristics. The fault dictionaries embody possible fault effects of the given fault types, devices, and circuits.	##false@@false$$	Home Page	##false@@true$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Reconfigurable Reliability and Security Engine; Security Engine; Security Engine; VHDL; 	PERSON: Iyer; 	NOUN: Professor Iyer; techniques; systems; projects; area; project; Reliability; Security Engine; framework; reliability; security; Reliability; Security Engine project; Illinois; framework; variety; application-aware techniques; error-detection; masking; security vulnerabilities; recovery; umbrella; uniform; manner; error-detection; security mechanisms; modules; framework; Reliability; Security Engine; RSE; part; microprocessor; hardware modules; parallel; core pipeline; goal; project; runtime checking techniques; failures; attacks; project Professor Iyer; DEPEND; framework; systems; DEPEND; environment; design; systems; fault tolerance; availability; inputs; VHDL; C; system description; output dependability characteristics; fault coverage; availability; performance; core; DEPEND; simulation engines; fault injector; set; fault dictionaries; component libraries; fault injector; mechanisms; faults; component libraries; model-building; descriptions; characteristics; fault dictionaries; fault effects; fault types; devices; circuits; Home Page; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@true$$

Chang is an Associate Professor in Computer Science, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He received a BS from National Taiwan University and PhD from Stanford University, in Electrical Engineering. His research addresses large scale information access, currently focusing on Web data-aware search, information integration, and mining. He received a VLDB Best Papers Selection in 2000, an NSF CAREER Award in 2002, an NCSA Faculty Fellow Award in 2003, IBM Faculty Awards in 2004 and 2005, Academy for Entrepreneurial Leadership Faculty Fellow Award in 2008, and the Incomplete List of Excellent Teachers at University of Illinois in 2001 and 2004. He loves to bring research results to the real world and, with his students, co-founded Cazoodle, a startup from the University of Illinois, for deepening "data-aware" search over the web.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; National Taiwan University; Stanford University; NSF; IBM; Academy for Entrepreneurial Leadership Faculty Fellow Award; University of Illinois; University of Illinois; 	PERSON: Kevin C. His research interests lie in scientific computing and parallel  computing. His post-doctoral research with Jack Dongarra at the University of  Tennessee, Knoxville concerns the implementation of linear algebra routines on  modern multi-core and GPU architectures. Previously, he worked at the National  Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), researching high-performance  wide-area networking, and at Lawrence Livermore National Lab (LLNL),  investigating ODE solvers and parallel linear algebra methods.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; University of Tennessee; GPU; National Center; NCSA; Lawrence Livermore National Lab; 	PERSON: Dr. Mark Gates; Jack Dongarra; 	LOCATION: Knoxville; 	NOUN: Dr. Mark Gates; Ph.D.; computer science; University; Illinois; Urbana-Champaign; research; implementation; volume correlation; method; engineering; research interests; computing; computing; research; Jack Dongarra; University; Tennessee; Knoxville; implementation; algebra routines; GPU architectures; National Center; Supercomputing Applications; NCSA; wide-area networking; Lawrence Livermore National Lab; LLNL; ODE solvers; algebra methods; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@true$$

adsc52-0 14 1----Research----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	can:1 engin:2 entertain:1 sculptur:1 recent:1 endeavour:1 push:1 confer:1 idmi:1 frontier:1 compris:1 confin:1 student:1 constantli:1 multidisciplinari:1 won:1 artist:1 institut:1 displai:1 imagin:1 taipei:1 global:1 flat:1 recognit:1 shape:2 team:1 tune:1 technolog:1 research:2 morph:1 demolish:1 digit:2 differ:2 advanc:1 nov:1 sing:1 intern:1 comput:1 interact:1 media:1 feat:1 world:1	||	IMAGINE sculptures which can morph into different shapes and "singing" different tunes with each new shape - this would not be just an artistic feat but also an Engineering endeavour. Researchers have constantly been pushing the frontiers of 3D displays, demolishing the confines of a flat digital world. A multidisciplinary team comprising researchers from the Interactive Digital Media Institute (IDMI) and Engineering students recently won global recognition at the 7th International Conference on Advances in Computer Entertainment Technology in Taipei (Nov, 2010) - for doing just this.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Interactive Digital Media Institute; 7th International Conference on Advances in Computer Entertainment Technology; 	DATE: 2010; 	LOCATION: Taipei; 	NOUN: sculptures; shapes; singing; tunes; shape; feat; Engineering endeavor; Researchers; frontiers; 3D displays; confines; world; team; researchers; Interactive Digital Media Institute; IDMI; Engineering students; recognition; 7th International Conference; Advances; Computer Entertainment Technology; Taipei; Nov; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

It included an electromagnetic system which is connected to an interactive tablet which looks like a giant iPad. But instead of the iPad's digital touch screen, the tablet sports a "liquid interface" -- and instead of using a finger to touch the "screen", a magnetic wand can be waved over the liquid to create ripples and various shapes (see picture, left). Each of the "shapes" formed on the liquid plays a corresponding music note -- and one could actually play an entire song - Beethoven's "	##false@@false$$	Ode to Joy"	##true@@false$$	by wielding the wand. I served as SIGMOD vice chair from 2001-5, and was on the editorial boards of ACM Transactions on Database Systems from 1994-2004 and IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering from 1994-8. I am an ACM Fellow, and I received a Presidential Young Investigator Award from the National Science Foundation in 1989. I received my PhD in Computer Science from Stanford University in 1987. 402758-2 9 11----Others----#text.P.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	integr:1 store:1 threat:1 possibl:1 perform:2 dbm:1 subtl:1 open:1 time:1 overhead:1 requir:1 correct:2 file:1 fraudul:1 propag:1 busi:1 relat:2 year:1 extrem:1 throughout:1 worm:3 support:1 runtim:1 immut:2 dai:1 provid:1 log:2 without:1 continu:2 much:1 present:1 record:1 transact:4 compromis:1 fast:1 propos:3 can:1 paper:1 proof:1 add:1 activ:3 affect:1 enterpris:1 real:1 versu:1 retent:1 expos:1 leverag:1 sarban:1 trustworthi:1 detect:1 helper:1 previous:3 tupl:1 guarante:1 audit:6 us:1 hour:1 offer:1 tlow:5 storag:1 kernel:1 research:1 tpc:2 impos:1 eg:1 effect:1 term:2 intern:1 oxlei:1 approach:4 inspir:1 server:1 chang:1 act:1 ah:1	||	The Sarbanes-Oxley Act inspired research on long-term high-integrity retention of business records, leveraging the immutability guarantees that WORM storage servers offer for files.  In this paper, we present the {\it transaction log on WORM} (TLOW) approach for supporting long-term immutability for relational tuples. TLOW stores the transaction log on WORM and uses an audit helper (AH) add-on to continuously perform audit-related activities without compromising transaction performance or audit trustworthiness.  TLOW imposes only 1-11\% runtime overhead on TPC-C transactions, much less than previously proposed approaches, and does not require DBMS kernel changes.  TLOW audits are extremely fast, e.g., two hours to audit a year of continuous TPC-C activity, versus 10 days for previously proposed approaches.  This opens up the possibility of real-time internal audits that can detect fraudulent activity before its effects propagate throughout an enterprise.  We also provide a proof of correctness for TLOW, which exposes a subtle threat that affects the correctness of previously proposed approaches.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: TLOW; DBMS; 	NOUN: Sarbanes-Oxley Act; research; retention; business records; immutability; WORM storage servers; files; paper; transaction log; WORM; TLOW; approach; immutability; tuples; TLOW stores; transaction log; WORM; audit helper; AH; activities; transaction performance; audit trustworthiness; TLOW; % runtime overhead; TPC-C transactions; approaches; DBMS kernel changes; TLOW audits; hours; year; TPC-C activity; days; approaches; possibility; audits; activity; effects; enterprise; proof; correctness; TLOW; threat; correctness; approaches; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

402758-2 9 15----Others----#text.P.DIV.LI.UL.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	can:1 delet:3 subject:1 threat:1 expir:1 litig:3 oper:1 request:1 relat:2 mean:1 expos:1 vacuum:3 masquerad:1 tupl:4 unexpir:1 plaintiff:1 hold:2 remov:1 audit:1 discoveri:1 period:1 access:1 illeg:1 databas:3 inform:3 mechan:1 thwart:1 defend:1 case:1 ask:1 phase:1 try:1 adversari:1	||	Relational databases are periodically vacuumed to remove tuples that have expired. During the discovery phase of litigation, plaintiffs ask defendants for access to information related to their case. The requested information is then subject to a litigation hold, which means that the information cannot be deleted. Vacuuming exposes a database to a new threat -- adversaries can try to thwart database auditing mechanism by masquerading an illegal tuple deletion as a vacuuming operation, and delete an unexpired tuple, or a tuple under a litigation hold.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: databases; tuples; discovery phase; litigation; plaintiffs; defendants; access; information; case; information; litigation hold; information; database; threat; adversaries; database auditing mechanism; tuple deletion; operation; tuple; tuple; litigation hold; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

She has been the director of the Advanced Digital Sciences Center in Singapore since 2009. She is an ACM Fellow and the recipient of a Presidential Young Investigator Award from the US National Science Foundation. She is the former vice-chair of ACM SIGMOD and has served on the editorial boards of ACM Transactions on the Web, ACM Transactions on Database Systems, IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering, ACM Transactions on Information and Systems Security, and the Very Large Data Bases Journal. She has received best paper awards for research on managing regulatory compliance data (VLDB and SSS), analyzing browser extensions to detect security vulnerabilities (Usenix Security), and keyword search (ICDE). Her PhD is from Stanford University.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer Science; University of Illinois; Advanced Digital Sciences Center; US National Science Foundation; ACM Transactions on Database Systems; Data Engineering; ACM Transactions on Information and Systems Security; Very Large Data Bases Journal; SSS; Stanford University; 	PERSON: Marianne Winslett; 	DATE: 1987; 2009; 	LOCATION: Singapore; 	NOUN: Marianne Winslett; professor; Department; Computer Science; University; Illinois; director; Advanced Digital Sciences Center; Singapore; ACM Fellow; Presidential Young Investigator Award; US National Science Foundation; vice-chair; ACM SIGMOD; editorial boards; ACM Transactions; Web; ACM Transactions; Database Systems; IEEE Transactions; Knowledge; Data Engineering; ACM Transactions; Information; Systems Security; Data Bases Journal; paper awards; research; compliance data; VLDB; SSS; browser extensions; security vulnerabilities; Usenix Security; search; ICDE; PhD; Stanford University; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
402758-2 20 3----Presentation----#text.P.TD.TR.TBODY.TABLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	societ:1 birth:1 govern:1 integr:1 reason:1 abil:1 becom:1 requir:1 busi:1 power:1 inaccur:1 dead:1 famou:1 elect:1 evid:1 compani:1 vote:1 behind:1 class:1 cost:1 without:1 goal:1 content:1 statement:1 record:4 peopl:1 often:1 determin:1 leav:1 can:1 inappropri:1 paper:1 date:1 ensur:1 gymnast:1 retent:1 easi:1 electron:3 major:1 sarban:1 abstract:1 law:1 uncertain:1 detect:1 perhap:1 trust:1 regul:1 us:2 problem:1 alter:1 address:1 term:1 replac:1 oxlei:1 insid:1 chang:2 act:1 financi:1 world:1	||	Abstract:	##true@@false$$	Inaccurate financial statements from major companies, dead people who still vote in elections, world-class gymnasts with uncertain birth dates: insiders often have the power and ability to make inappropriate changes to the content of electronic records. As electronic records replace paper records, it becomes easy to make such alterations without leaving behind evidence that can be used to detect the changes and determine who made them. The US Sarbanes-Oxley Act is perhaps the most (in)famous law that addresses these problems, but it is just one of many regulations that require long-term high-integrity retention of electronic records, all with the goal of ensuring that societal trust in business and government at reasonable cost.	##false@@false$$		||	LOCATION: US; 	NOUN: statements; companies; people; elections; gymnasts; birth dates; insiders; power; ability; changes; content; records; records; paper records; alterations; evidence; changes; US Sarbanes-Oxley Act; law; problems; regulations; retention; records; goal; trust; business; government; cost; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$

Before that, I worked for Bell Labs.  My research interests lie in  information security and in the management of scientific data.  I am currently on the editorial boards of ACM Transactions on the Web and ACM Transactions on Information and System Security. I served as SIGMOD vice chair from 2001-5,  and was on the editorial boards of ACM Transactions on Database Systems from 1994-2004 and    IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering from 1994-8. I am an ACM Fellow, and  I received a Presidential Young Investigator Award from the National Science Foundation in 1989.  I received my PhD in Computer Science from Stanford University in 1987. My recent publications  can be found under the web pages listed in the top right corner;  a relatively complete list of publications can be found at	##false@@false$$	DBLP	##false@@true$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Department of Computer Science; University of Illinois; Bell Labs; ACM Transactions on Information and System Security; SIGMOD; Database Systems; ACM Fellow; National Science Foundation; Stanford University; 	DATE: 1987; 1989; 1987; 	NOUN: Bio; professor; Department; Computer Science; University; Illinois; assistant; associate; adjunct; research professor; Bell Labs; research interests; information security; management; data; editorial boards; ACM Transactions; Web; ACM Transactions; Information; System Security; SIGMOD vice chair; editorial boards; ACM Transactions; Database Systems; IEEE Transactions; Knowledge; Data Engineering; ACM Fellow; Presidential Young Investigator Award; National Science Foundation; PhD; Computer Science; Stanford University; publications; web pages; right corner; list; publications; DBLP; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Theredesign was coordinated by Jeffrey Xu Yu and mainly done by two postgraduate students Qi Pan and Zheng Liu (Chinese University of Hong Kong). There have been four Information Directors to date: Alberto Mendelzon (University of Toronto) 1997-2002, Mario Nascimento ((University of Alberta) 2003, Alexandros Labrinidis (University of Pittsburgh) 2004-2006, and Jeffrey Xu Yu (Chinese University of Hong Kong) (2007-). The website has been maintained along with a team Associate Information Directors, and many other individuals currently make or have made substantial contributions to SIGMOD Online as well including: Richard Snodgrass, Marcelo Arenas, Denilson Barbosa, Ugur Cetintemel, Curtis Dyreson, Manfred Jeusfeld, Alexandros Labrinidis, Dongwon Lee, Michael Ley, Rachel Pottinger, Altigran Soares da Silva, Marianne Winslett, and Jun Yang.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: University of Toronto; University of Alberta; University of Pittsburgh; Chinese University; Associate Information Directors; 	PERSON: Alberto Mendelzon; Mario Nascimento; Alexandros Labrinidis; Jeffrey Xu Yu; Richard Snodgrass; Marcelo Arenas; Denilson Barbosa; Ugur Cetintemel; Curtis Dyreson; Manfred Jeusfeld; Alexandros Labrinidis; Dongwon Lee; Michael Ley; Rachel Pottinger; Altigran Soares da Silva; Marianne Winslett; Jun Yang; 	DATE: 2003; 2007; 	LOCATION: Hong Kong; 	NOUN: position; SIGMOD Executive Committee; late1997; Information Directors; date; Alberto Mendelzon; University; Toronto; Mario Nascimento; University; Alberta; Alexandros Labrinidis; University; Pittsburgh; Jeffrey Xu Yu; Chinese University; Hong Kong; website; team Associate Information Directors; individuals; contributions; SIGMOD Online; Richard Snodgrass; Marcelo Arenas; Denilson Barbosa; Ugur Cetintemel; Curtis Dyreson; Manfred Jeusfeld; Alexandros Labrinidis; Dongwon Lee; Michael Ley; Rachel Pottinger; Altigran Soares da Silva; Marianne Winslett; Jun Yang; 	||	##false@@false$$	||	##true@@false$$
